The government's newly announced measures to combat people smuggling include the international information campaign `Pay a people smuggler and you'll pay the price' and the recent announcement overseas of shock television images of crocodiles and sharks warning people not to pay a people smuggler to come to Australia. It is yet to be seen whether these initiatives will do anything to curb the people smuggling epidemic. Some might argue, if you want to scare people away from coming to Australia, that we should forget about images of man-eating crocodiles and sharks and show them images of small business owners trying to get ready for the GST.

The Labor opposition has repeatedly called for the establishment of a national coast guard which would alleviate the responsibility of detecting illegal arrivals from being shared between Coastwatch, the Navy and Australian Customs. This would more effectively help deal with the people smuggling problem because it would be a central and unified agency which could concentrate a large proportion of its resources on catching the individuals who profit out of this scurrilous trade. This way, if we can stamp out and go after the people smuggling racketeers, the cost of detaining and keeping illegal immigrants is significantly reduced as fewer would be arriving. Eventually, a reduction in illegal arrivals would allow those people who have been patiently waiting in line to be reunited with their families a quicker and smoother wait for their applications to proceed.

Illegal migration has a direct effect on the number of migration visas that are approved. In February this year, the minister ordered a freeze in processing of offshore refugee visas because there were so many onshore applications pending. I am not questioning that, but trying to explain that to the people I represent is very difficult indeed. The minister said in the Australian on 15 February 2000 that this freeze was a natural consequence of the wave of illegal immigrants. I pose the question: if this bill becomes law, will these people who have paid anywhere up to $64,000 to enter the country have their visa applications put on hold as soon as we get another sudden increase in illegal arrivals? $64,000 is a massive and unfair increase in the processing of parent immigration visas. However, what is most concerning is the minister's comments to the effect that $25,000 is really only one-fifth of the potential health costs, which are estimated at around $120,000.

In the cases I have already mentioned, a cost of up to $125,000 will be totally and completely unreasonable and unnecessary as the sponsors have assured us that the parents will be self-sufficient, financially independent and in good health. I ask the minister to think about what sort of migration policy we want here in Australia. As the minister says, migration policy is about the way we want to see ourselves as a nation. But it is also about how we want other nations to see us. I do not know about the minister, but I do know that I want Australia to be seen as a friendly and welcoming nation which has a migration policy that encompasses integrity and humanity and offers all manner of benefits in Australia, not just purely economic benefits.

I repeat that the $64,000 set by the government is excessive and unreasonable. It sends a message out to the people smugglers that Australia's immigration policy can be compromised by the forces of the dollar. I cannot support a bill which says quite clearly that if you have money, with no questions asked about how it was obtained, you are welcome to join the rest of your family in Australia. I cannot support a bill which will have the consequences of families incurring large debts at interest rates at times in excess of 25 per cent or higher. I cannot support a bill proposed by a government which talks so much about cracking down on queue jumping yet in one fell swoop advocates a form of queue jumping for the haves but not for the have nots.

The member for Hindmarsh asked what we would do. I can inform her, the minister and every member of the government, as has been stated time and time again, that we would certainly look at working with the government in this area but not while they propose the exorbitant fees that have now been plucked at random out of a hat. We have to give consideration to the majority of people who wish to be reunited with their families, but it has to be done in a fair and reasonable way. It has to be done in such a way that people who are now coming here illegally will know that they are not welcome in this country; but those who are making the proper contribution to this country as legal migrants should at least reach a point in their lives some time in the future when, if it is permissible, they can go through the proper channels and have their parents or loved ones with them to provide support. This is what we should be doing in an immigration policy. It should not be driven by the almighty dollar. There is more to humanity and more to the human being than what the dollar can buy. I believe that most of the government members would join me if they talked to their constituents and listened to some of the heartfelt agony that people are going through because of this legislation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am particularly pleased to rise in support of the Migration Legislation Amendment (Parents and Other Measures) Bill 2000. In this House last year I spoke of my extremely strong disappointment with the voting down in the Senate of the Migration Amendment Regulation 1998,which would have allowed the children of elderly parents living overseas to sponsor them to migrate to Australia under a new visa subclass. This disallowance caused considerable distress to many constituents in my electorate of Moore who were willing to pay an additional assurance of support in order to expedite the visa process and, at the same time, ensure their relatives were not an undue burden on the Australian taxpayer. Further distress was caused as many parents were being processed under this new subclass when the decision was made in the Senate to deny these people the opportunity to be reunited with their families in Australia.

speech.para: It was not an easy task to explain to the families in my electorate why their parents should have to go back into the queue for the old visa, where there is a cap each year of 500 applicants, especially given the reasons of the non--government parties in the Senate for the disallowance. Despite the high level of interest of families in Australia in taking advantage of the new visa, the Labor Party denied them the opportunity because they said it was a visa for the rich. This was even harder to explain to my constituents, who were by no means wealthy—just prepared, along with their parents, to contribute towards the cost of being reunited with their family. Fortunately, the designated parent visa category was made available in November last year to assist the parents who were victimised by the Senate's decision. This incorporated the previous arrangements of the Migration Amendment Regulation, and nearly all of the applicants from the previous visa class moved over to this new category of visa.

This bill will allow for an intake of up to 4,000 parents over the next two years under the federal government's immigration program, in addition to existing visas that are available to parents. Those in the designated parent visa class will continue to be processed under that visa. The new entry arrangements under this bill ask for an assurance of support for a period of 10 years instead of the current two. This is in line with the current 10-year waiting period before elderly migrants are able to access the age pension. The bond for the assurance of support will rise from $3,500 to $10,000 for the main applicant and from $1,500 to $4,000 for other adult dependants. This will be repaid to the applicants after the 10 years if they have not accessed any welfare benefits during that time. The interest on that bond will also be repaid to the applicants. The applicants will then have a choice of taking out suitable private health insurance for the first 10 years or paying a health bond of $25,000 to contribute to the cost of their health needs in that time.

Another welcome aspect of this bill makes for more flexible arrangements for parents who are currently waiting for approval for a visa but who wish to visit their families in the meantime. In terms of health care during that time, many of these parents will be able to access reciprocal arrangements within Medicare. Otherwise, they will not have access to Medicare whilst on a visitors visa. This visa and the previously disallowed visa were introduced by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs after his extensive consultations when travelling around the country to discuss Australia's immigration program. One of these public meetings was held in my electorate, and I commend the minister on his willingness to listen to my constituents. For an immigration program to be successful, it is important to give members of the public, who often feel alienated by the political decision making process, a chance to put their views to the minister—and I know he is a good listener.

Parent visas, under which more elderly parents have the opportunity to come to Australia if they are prepared to contribute towards the cost of their care, have been welcomed by both the general public and the major peak bodies involved in immigration issues. It is a commonsense measure that allows new Australians the means of bringing their parents to Australia while not being an unfair burden on the taxpayer. Those who have worked and paid taxes all their lives in another country should not move to this country and receive the benefits that people here pay taxes for. They should not expect to be fully supported. The many families that I have had contact with who wish to see their parents join them in Australia accept this as a fair means of entering the country. As I said earlier, all the peak bodies involved in immigration believe this is a fair measure. It is now up to the Senate to listen to the wishes of their constituents.

Another reason why many of the families have absolutely no problem with supporting their parents, or helping the parents support themselves, is that this is not an unusual request in the immigration laws of other countries. Australia is not asking for something out of the ordinary when it asks newly arrived migrants to be self-supporting. For example, elderly parents wanting to emigrate to the United Kingdom to join their children who migrated from Australia would only be granted a visa if they were wholly or mainly financially dependent on the sponsor. They are unable to access any public funds—that is, state benefits such as income support, housing assistance, thejob seekers allowance and disability payments.

This new parent visa will help to free up the existing parent visa category which has a cap of 500 applicants per year, so those people unable or unwilling to pay an increased assurance of support will have their visas approved in a shorter time frame as many applicants ahead of them in the queue move over to the new visa. This surely must keep the member for Prospect happy. A recent survey completed by the National Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders University showed that three-quarters of migrants surveyed in Australia had a parent living overseas. After three years of settlement, 15 per cent of the sample surveyed had sponsored or applied to sponsor a close relative to migrate to Australia. A further 18 per cent indicated they were planning to sponsor a relative in the near future. At present there are about 20,000 parents waiting to obtain a visa to migrate to Australia. The sponsoring of elderly parents will always be a major component of any immigration program in this country, so it is important that we get this right. As this House has already heard, the average cost of looking after the health of someone over the age of 65 is estimated at $6,000 a year. As a community, we have to balance the wishes of new Australians to be reunited with their parents and the effect this will have on the public purse. This is not to say we should ignore the many positive benefits of bringing parents out to Australia, particularly in terms of family support. I call on the non-government parties in this House to stop the ideological nonsense about visas for the rich and support this practical, widely popular and fair measure. I commend this Bill to the House. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate does not insist on its requests for amendments Nos 1 and 2 to which the House has disagreed and agrees to the amendment made by the House in place of the Senate's request No. 1 and has made a further request for amendments.
Ordered that the further requested amendments be considered at the next sitting.

debate.para: The following bills were returned from the Senate without amendment or request:

para.inline: Financial Management and Accountability Amendment Bill 2000

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I am very concerned about the debate that is currently raging about the effect on rent of the GST. On the one hand, we have a commitment that the GST will not apply to normal private household rent and, on the other, we have an acknowledgment that landlords will probably pass on costs associated with the property although GST as a direct charge on rent would not occur. I believe the government's estimate on the potential increase on these rents as I have described was around 2.3 per cent. Now we have a report, seemingly kept under wraps at first by the government, by the government's preferred economic modeller, Econtech, which predicts that increase is now to be around 4.7 per cent. Earlier this week, the Treasurer translated that with some pretty smart figuring into an increase of about $8 to $10 a week, which he then went on to describe as `affordable for the average family'. As we have pointed out, if that average family is on a dual income of $45,000, has two children—what I would consider a pretty average family—and receives $25 a week tax cuts as part of the GST package, this means $8 to $10 a week going immediately into rent really cuts quite a swathe into that tax cut which is the compensation method for the cost of the GST coming on stream. This is long before that average family even begins to cover other increased costs of living associated with the GST. It seems to me that the Treasurer and the government really do not see the reality of these imposts on our families and on our communities. In my electorate of Canberra I understand there are over 11,000 households, or 22.5 per cent of the community, in private rental which stand to be affected by this new projected outcome. Rent makes a very large hole in a family's income. I do not believe that our families can simply just keep absorbing all of these rising costs.

speech.para: We also have the debate about rent on long-stay caravan park residents and people who live in boarding houses. The government has never denied that GST will be charged directly on their rent. Some of these people have chosen this lifestyle as their only economic means of owning their own dwelling. In bringing this issue to the fore from this side of the parliament we have been vilified as scaremongering or as troublemaking. Despite that, the pressure on the government has been sufficient that another series of Democrat-government meetings has been held to devise a way out of this electoral mess—that is how they see this, not as an unfair treatment of people but as a threat in electoral terms.

What is the solution they have come up with? The Democrats' deal with the government to compensate the GST rent hikes is shameful. For a single social security recipient with no children the deal is worth just 16c extra per day. Only social security recipients receiving the maximum rate of rent assistance will receive the increase. For most social security recipients who do not receive the maximum rate the deal does not deliver any money at all—not one cent. We intend to move amendments to this legislation to ensure the removal of the GST charge from these people completely. That is how this issue should be solved, not by dabbling around the edges in a shameful way, by pretending that some compensation package has been devised overnight purely because of the electoral pressure being now felt by sectors of the government. The only real way of dealing with this issue is to remove the possibility of charging the GST to those people in the first place.

We keep hearing about 1 July, the day it all begins. That is true—it is the day it is supposed to all begin—but for many of these families it has already, directly or indirectly, well and truly begun, long before any so-called `compensation' packages have even remotely become available. I am saddened by the apparent ignorance and absolute inability of this government to see what is really happening out there. When I stand up in this place and talk about my community, my families, my constituents, who are coming to me of their own free will to tell me how this whole scenario is affecting them—they are telling me, I am not telling them—my job is to come in here and make sure that the government hears that message. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Caravan Parks
Robertson Electorate: Gosford Under 17 Netball Team
AESOP Business Volunteers Ltd

subdebate.1.title: Robertson Electorate: Gosford Under 17 Netball Team
AESOP Business Volunteers Ltd

talk.start.para: —I was not planning to talk on the rental in caravan parks issue, but I think I should make a couple of comments following the previous member's comments. This is a complex issue. It is one that I have been very concerned about. If the Labor Party were to introduce their amendment it would simply increase the cost of running a caravan park or a mobile home park. Those increased costs would be passed on to tenants and residents. The Labor Party amendment would simply mean that those tenants would end up paying increased rents. At least this government has increased their compensation. Most of the residents, certainly in my electorate, would receive the maximum amount of rental assistance. I think they will find after 1 July that the compensation package will more than cover any increases that they will suffer.

speech.para: Tonight I want to congratulate the Gosford Under 17 Netball Team on their fantastic win at the state championships at the recent long weekend at Baulkam Hills. The results meant that the Gosford under 17 team took out the minor division. The team played strongly in difficult weather conditions. They played 19 games, and conceded only one draw to Eastwood Ryde over the whole three days—a fantastic effort. The team consisted of the shooters Vicki Ward, Michelle Tarring and Rebecca Birch, who averaged 90 per cent in the goal scoring. They had the defence of Jade Kestle and Rani Blakeney. They were assisted by the mid-court players Jessica Jackson, Camille Mason, Stephanie Rofe and Lauren Van Munster. The coach is Annette Podryhula and the manageress is Mariana Jackson. It was a great effort by that team. I want to congratulate them tonight and put it on the record.

I also wanted to speak of something that is not a local issue but something that I would like to highlight. It is the AESOP Business Volunteers Ltd, a not-for-profit service organisation that a lot of people do not know about. It is important to highlight what a valuable service this group provides all around the world. They were formed in 1981. They are basically volunteers, often retired professional people who provide management and technical training assistance to businesses and institutions in developing countries in the Asia Pacific region and also to indigenous organisations and businesses within Australia.

Often developing countries do not have the skills needed to run small or large businesses. They are able to have the facilities and expertise of people from Australia who volunteer their time to go into those countries to give them those skills. AESOP is contracted by the Australian government through AusAID. I made a speech in parliament recently on the valuable work of AusAID, particularly in the Pacific island nations. I thought tonight was a good opportunity to highlight one of the arms of AusAID, AESOP. There are over 2,000 people registered on their database, with expertise across a wide range of private and public sector businesses. These volunteers have a proven track record in their respective fields and they have many years of practical experience behind them. They are normally highly motivated people who are interested in helping, and donate their time free of charge. Often they have to pay their own transport costs to go to those countries. The companies will in many cases provide them with meals and accommodation in these countries. In return they provide the assistance and professional advice that is needed to help developing countries.

Some of the countries that AESOP volunteers are involved in are: the Cook Islands, Fiji, Micronesia, Indonesia, Kiribati, Nauru, Laos, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, the Solomon Islands, Vanuatu, Tonga, Vietnam, Thailand, Tuvalu and Samoa. It shows that there is so much that Australian volunteers do overseas. Most of these people never get the publicity of what Australia is doing, particularly in the Pacific island regions. With the unrest that is happening in the Solomons and Fiji at the moment, it is a difficult time for them. I just wanted the Australian community to realise what a valuable role so many great Australians play through AusAID and through AESOP in what they are doing throughout those areas.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Price Increases

talk.start.para: —Tonight, I want to speak about the GST and some of its impacts. With the debate raging and the number of phone calls to my office increasing from small business people concerned about how the GST is going to affect them and how it is costing them to implement it, I thought I would take the Prime Minister's advice—which we were told regularly in question time—not to take it on trust but to check it out for myself. So today I decided that I would ring the ACCC help line, and I would like to share with the House how you are greeted. It says: `Welcome to the ACCC GST price-line. Please choose one of the two following options: if you understand English, please press 1; if you do not understand English, please press 2.'

speech.para: It is impossible not to bring to mind John Profumo who, when questioned in the House of Commons about what instructions had been given to the troops in case they got lost during the Suez campaign, replied, `The troops were told that they should immediately rejoin their units.' With this quality of advice, it is no surprise that there is such a level of confusion amongst Australians about how the GST is going to affect them. And they have not been helped by the `Unchain' advertisements, which are really nothing more than a self-promotion exercise, and a very costly one, by this government.

Of course amongst the people who should choose option 2 is the Treasurer, as he struggles to explain the impossible. I am sure that a number of members would have heard the Treasurer on AM the other day taking 10 minutes to explain how the GST will impact on rents. Neither I nor any other English speaking listener thought he made any sense at all. The Treasurer is now speaking a new language called `GST-speak'. He has created a whole raft of new and unique expressions, all of which translate into: `We are going to pay more.'

The government cannot be surprised when the people in the streets are confused, when his own frontbench is struggling to explain the GST and they themselves are confused. The Minister for Community Services agrees that the GST on permanent caravan park residents is unfair. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business let the cat out of the bag the other day when he said that the GST is going to collect twice the amount that the government has admitted it will. Mr Howard quickly said that the minister does not know what he is talking about—of course, we have been saying that for some time on this side of the House—but this time I think what he said does have a ring of credibility, and in a year's time I bet I know who will be proven right about the amount of GST that will have been collected.

The list of promises broken by the government has grown longer and longer since last election. We all remember these promises: beer will not increase by more than 1.9 per cent; residential rents will not increase; no-one will be worse off; permanent caravan park residents and park home owners will not be affected; education will be GST free; health will be GST free. So far beer is going to increase by significantly more than 1.9 per cent. There will be an impact on residential rents. Many people are worse off, mainly those at the lower end of the economic spectrum. Permanent caravan park residents and park home owners are being affected. The GST will have an impact on many of the costs associated with education, and the same for health.

Australians have been trapped by the government, because they did not pick the option which translated the government's promises. When told today that there will be an increased rent allowance for those living permanently in caravan parks or park homes, they were not told that this will help only those who are already receiving a government benefit; it will not offer any relief to self-funded retirees or those living in park homes who do not receive a government allowance. They will become part of that select group who pay GST on their residential rent. The great pity of it is that the GST is an unfair tax. We do know that it is unfair and that it is going to have the hardest impact on those who can least afford it. What makes it even worse is the confused, ham-fisted and inept way the government has introduced this tax. It has cost small business much more than they can afford and it has caused huge amounts of stress and confusion that will go on for quite some time.

talk.start.para: —On Monday during the condolence motion for the late Mr Greg Wilton, the member for Grayndler said in his excellent contribution that every member of the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration of the previous parliament had spoken to the condolence motion. Well, I had not. I was a member of that committee up until September 1997. I did not speak to the condolence motion not because I did not care about Mr Wilton but because I did not know him well. I must say from my experience of him in the committee he seemed to be an intelligent, diligent and well-informed advocate for his party and certainly for his electorate.

speech.para: The other reason I did not speak was that these kinds of tragedies—things that we find so difficult to understand and come to terms with—are played out every day in the lives of the people whom we represent. I think it is not until it actually affects one of us—in this case someone in our workplace and for many of my colleagues on the Labor side of the House someone who was their dear friend—that we realise just what a toll is being taken by self-harm and, in particular, suicide in our society. It is an indictment of all of us and our society that over the last 15 to 20 years we have reduced the toll taken by disease and accident, yet we have failed to have any impact on the toll exacted by despair, particularly for men—of which Greg spoke after the Standing Committee on Family and Community Affairs had published our report on aspects of suicide. In fact, for men, it has been getting worse.

Whilst I did not know Greg at all well during his life, my observation is that in his death he has given us two gifts. The first gift he gave to us in this parliament and to the people whom we represent, and that is that he forced us to pause for four or five or six hours and reflect on who we are, why we are here, how we relate to one another and perhaps what our roles might be in trying to change a society that yields so slowly to measures which might reduce the toll taken by suicide.

The second gift I think he has left for his children is in such a compelling and clear way to demonstrate to them, and certainly to me, that, in the end, any of us will be remembered not for how much wealth we have, what position we acquire in life or what spectrum of influential friends we might have, but for who we are. The things I found so moving that were said by many of my colleagues on Monday related not to the fact that he was the member for Isaacs but because he was considered to be a good person, a person who had committed his life through a sense of idealism to making his country a better place.

The question was asked repeatedly, as we still do, I suppose: why should this sort of thing occur? I do not think anybody can seriously answer why depression, and in particular why suicide, is so prevalent. But one of the observations I would make—and I think one person made reference to the issue of euthanasia, which we had debated so earnestly—is that during the euthanasia debate so many of my colleagues who are well intentioned seemed to almost trivialise the decision that might be taken in terms of intentionally ending another person's life. But I do not think there was a person in this parliament on Monday who could not be persuaded to the view that life is precious and that for despair, whatever its origin—whatever the despair that led Greg Wilton to take his life, the despair of those who face what they believe are insurmountable problems—death is not really a legitimate solution to the things that overwhelm us. I do not think anybody in the parliament would have accepted that on Monday. It just seems that, in a world of vast economic change and unprecedented technological uncertainty, it is so clear—and I think the message that Greg left to his children—that the thing we need most is one another, as imperfect as we may be.

talk.start.para: —As honourable members realise from working in their electorates, there are lots of calls on our time by a whole series of organisations. Due to the time constraints, one is forced to prioritise and pick those we really want to get involved in and others that we tend to flit in and out of. Tonight I would like to speak about one I am involved with, I guess peripherally, and that I am trying to dedicate as much time to assisting when I am home—that is, the scouting and guiding associations in Tasmania. As a young child growing up in Ballarat I was involved in the cubs, and when we moved to South Australia I had a passing interest in scouts. My father's movement around Australia because of his job meant that I did not get involved, but now I have the opportunity. The thing that amazes me in this day and age when there are so many calls on people's time is the fantastic job the dedicated group of individuals who are scout leaders, guide leaders and cub leaders do. All of them have their own full-time jobs and on various nights and at weekends not only do they undertake various training courses for themselves to ensure that the young people in their care are challenged constantly but also they dedicate countless hours to meetings and conducting the weekly courses for the various organisations they are responsible for.

speech.para: In this day and age when young people are constantly being challenged to put their money where their mouth is I find it rather strange that not only do these leaders but also the parents who support them—in many cases having their own boys and girls involved in the various organisations—are forced to work tirelessly to raise what, to my mind, are very small amounts of money in order to purchase tents, camping equipment, and boats in some cases, and in order to try to maintain the many buildings they have. It really worries me that here is a fantastic group of people involved in the scouting and guiding associations who are working tirelessly to provide kids with fantastic role models and challenging them every night when they operate the various venues, and yet they are expected to work virtually on a shoestring budget.

I think we as politicians need to look seriously at what we can do. I know we have enormous calls on our financial abilities to support and sponsor these groups, but towards the end of the year I know there is a jamboree to be held in Sydney as a part of the Olympic year. Scouts will be coming from all parts of the world to attend this international jamboree. I urge all members to inquire of the various scouting associations what we as individual members of this place can do to try to ensure that each and every one of those kids—irrespective of whether their parents are in the upper echelons of earning potential or whether they are kids with the backsides out of their trousers and whose parents see scouting as the only positive reinforcement of values they are having trouble imparting to their children—can attend. From the brief seven or eight years since I have been in this place and my involvement with these people, they absolutely amaze me. I think it is incumbent upon us to do whatever we can to ensure that these people, in my case in the Kingborough, Huon and eastern shore areas of the scouting associations, are supported in their endeavours. I am highlighting their wonderful role tonight. I challenge everybody in this place to get involved to ensure that the jamboree to be held in Sydney is a fantastic success and that as many kids as possible can attend. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I draw to the attention of the House the exciting new globulus blue gum industry that is now emerging in western Victoria. This amazing resurgence of agriculture is something that many wool growers are delighted about because they have seen a change in their capital structure. There has been a lot of controversy about the export of woodchips, but we now see the emergence of a new home grown industry, with the planting of globulus blue gum in the higher rainfall zones. This is based on the very simple fact that in China three kilograms per head of paper products is consumed, and in the USA it is nearer to about 80 kilograms per head. So it would seem that, as the Asian nations improve their standard of living, the demand for paper products will improve dramatically.

speech.para: The demand for quality paper, which the globulus blue gum fibre is eminently suitable to provide, is in high demand throughout the Western world. The change in technology in the production of these blue gums has ensured their growth rates are phenomenal. Speaking as a farmer who has tried to grow a number of trees over a lifetime, it is amazing to see that, with the introduction of new techniques of deep ripping—that is, ripping the soil up to two and three feet to ensure the roots grow more easily—and moulding, which is building up soil around the tree and spraying to keep weeds away, the growth of these trees in the first year can often reach five, six or 10 feet. Not only has there been a dramatic change in the production cycle but we now have the unusual situation in forestry whereby we can get two production cycles out of the one tree, so much so that in 12 years these globulus blue gums are in a position to be harvested.

In 26-inch rainfall areas, a number of these plantations are now being grown. That is about the lowest level, in my view, at which these trees can be grown, provided the soil is of the proper type and it will provide the fertility and the depth. In south-west Victoria, landowners have changed their capital values. In some cases, wool growers who had land worth $600 or $700 an acre, or even $500 an acre, are now selling out at between $1,200 and $1,400 an acre—a remarkable change in their productive performance.

This is a new industry, reflecting an influence of the tax system, where the costs of initially setting up a globulus plantation is written off from a tax point of view. There was some debate about the 13-month rule; however, a number of companies have been set up to take advantage of the tax situation for high income earners. It would be my hope, however, that this was productivity driven and that these plantations did result in an economic return on the funds invested. Compared with pine plantations, which were all the go some 25 years ago, it is my hope that they did not fall over in their return because the pine trees have not fulfilled their expectations. It is important to ensure that the road network is adequate to cover the woodchip plants that will be set up to support the globulus blue gum plantations that are springing up in south-west Victoria and South Australia and that the markets will be around in 12 and 20 years time.

I finally raise the very important right of the growers to harvest those trees. I am sure that the shadow minister, sitting opposite, will support me and will allow that to take place over the next 12 years and will not allow environmentalists to prevent the harvesting of these trees because they might develop different attitudes when they see the trees at full maturity. I put clearly on the record that this parliament should ensure that those investors who have invested in good faith will be able to harvest their product after 12 years, and hopefully after 24 years, on the basis that it is a crop and it is harvestable, and that those environmentalists who see these very good quality trees will not interfere. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to take the few minutes that are available to me to express my pleasure that the long, protracted dispute at the WTO involving Howe Leather has been resolved. It would be churlish of me to go over some of the critical comments that I have made along the way with respect to the way in which this has been handled. I think that we are all relieved that what had developed into a fairly nasty type of trade incident has been resolved. The retaliatory action that had been threatened by the US administration, which would have involved industries such as wine, citrus and auto components, was something that we had to fight hard to avoid.

speech.para: I am very pleased that the honourable member for Farrer is in the chamber. I hope I am correct when I say that I acknowledged his efforts very early in this case. While I may have made some comments about a judgment that he made about not appealing at a certain point in time—I had a different view from him; that view is on the record and I do not back away from that—I hope that collectively we have learnt a good lesson from this case, and that we understand that countries like the United States of America will fight these things very hard and that they will resource their efforts in the WTO to a great degree. I hope that, out of what has confronted us as a country with respect to this dispute, we will have learnt lessons which will ensure that, when similar circumstances arise, we might be able to go through the minefield that is the WTO with greater success.

I note that the NFF have made some comments about our confronting something like $28 billion worth of subsidy to American agricultural industries, as against this package of about $30 million in automotive leather, and the United States wants to play the game in a different way.

talk.start.para: —Might is not always right.

—I have to agree with the honourable member for Farrer. My problem, of course, is that I come from perhaps a minority view throughout the parliament about notions of fair trade. I am worried that incidents like Howe have given fair trade a bad name. The United States would perhaps say that they entered into this dispute in the name of fair trade. I believe that free trade has to be fair trade. I am very pleased that this has been resolved. It gives Howe and the people who work for them some hope. We know that companies like Howe can compete if given the opportunity.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise an issue in response to a press release from Senator Nick Minchin calling on the Senate to support state native title. You will recall, Mr Deputy Speaker, that Senator Minchin has been described as a liar by some of his colleagues as a result of some party room negotiations. In this instance, he is knowingly misleading the public in claiming that native title matters in three states are holding up exploration applications. There can be no doubt that we are experiencing a serious decline in outlays of mineral exploration in this country. For the past couple of generations, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, the only correlation with exploration activity was and remains base metal prices. The decline in greenfields exploration in this country predates the Mabo decision, as do early trends in the decline of brownfields exploration.

speech.para: In the past few years, there has been a well-documented exodus of risk capital from minerals exploration to dot com ventures. This shift has nothing to do with native title and everything to do with the trend to speculation inherent in stock markets. Serious players in the states are threatened not by the native title system, but rather by governments committed to thwarting the proper operation of the Native Title Act for political purposes. For example, despite all registered claims in place at the time of the 1998 amended act having to be reassessed by the standards of John Howard's new act, the Western Australian government has appealed against the registration of every claim that has successfully passed the John Howard test.

As recently as last Friday, we had notice that Premier Court intends to issue licences over land subject to native title claims in advance of determinations by the High Court on critical legal issues. We know where this has led us in the past. The validation regime in the Native Title Act amendments is all due to the fact that state governments would not heed the implications of the original Mabo decision. The problems of mineral exploration in this country are real and immediate. They deserve serious debate uncluttered by political motives. Spurious identification of the cause of a problem must inevitably delay or thwart lasting solutions.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you should also be aware, to highlight the absurdity of the statements by Senator Minchin, that, in the case of the Northern Territory, exploration was frozen for a number of years by a fiat of the Northern Territory government who refused to deal with the current Native Title Act and the right to negotiate regime. They have since come to their senses, but in effect, exploration was frozen by them, a conservative government. Senator Minchin needs to tell the truth.

talk.start.para: —There can be no doubt that the combination of young people and drugs is a deadly one. It is possibly one of the most pressing problems we face as a society and one for which there are no easy answers or quick fix solutions. Drugs do not discriminate. They infect the lives of people with all levels of education, income and opportunity. But there are organisations which can make inroads. In McPherson, the Life Education Centre in Broadbeach, under the direction of a dedicated man named Peter Fox, was helping to fight the dangerous consequences of drugs and addiction by providing positive health and anti-drug abuse prevention programs to thousands of Gold Coast students.

speech.para: Life Education Centres across the country work in partnership with schools to provide effective and essential drug education. In Queensland, Life Education has been running programs for 13 years. The program was reaching more than 150,000 Queensland students and over one million Australian students each year. Life Education sessions have proven to be an integral part of each school's drug education program and the methods it adopts are highly successful. In fact, according to Education Queensland evaluations, the program met 97 per cent to 99 per cent of the criteria. Why then did the Beattie Labor government completely cut funding to Life Education and leave impressionable young students without adequate anti-drug education? With expert after expert now advising that education is the key to winning the war against drugs, these funding cuts defy logic. To make matters worse, the Beattie government also dismantled Education Queensland's own internal drug education resource. In fact, the Premier singled-handedly dismantled drug education in Queensland full stop.

The Queensland government has always had an appalling record on drugs. A report released in June last year entitled Drug education in schools revealed that only 50c per student was being spent on antidrug education, compared to $10 in Victoria, for example. Until June 1999, Queensland had the lowest expenditure on drug education of any state in the country. After the latest round of cuts, our expenditure is now zero. In that same report, the Queensland government says its official position is that `Education Queensland will not accept responsibility for changing students' health behaviours, including drug use'.

Surely, the children of Queensland deserve better than this. Surely, these children deserve to grow up in a drug-free community. They deserve to be warned about the deadly effects of drugs. Is Premier Beattie prepared to face the next parent whose child has died from a drug addiction and tell them that antidrug education just was not one of his priorities? It is a disgrace which the next generation of young Australians will pay for. I call on the Queensland Premier to immediately reinstate funding to allow Life Education to deliver its essential antidrug message.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Caravan Parks and Boarding Houses

talk.start.para: —In 1996, the Australian Bureau of Statistics said that there were 161,000 Australians who were living as permanent residents of caravan parks. The difficulty, of course, is to work out how many others are living as residents of boarding houses, because there are no official figures for residents of boarding houses. The best estimate, according to Kate Wait, from the National Association of Tenants Organisation, is that about 300,000 people in total are living in both caravan parks and boarding houses. There are many boarding houses in my electorate and a large number of people who live in them are amongst the poorest and most vulnerable people that I represent.

speech.para: Many of the residents are elderly, frail or suffering from some physical or intellectual disability. The vast majority of residents are in receipt of unemployment benefits or age or disability pensions. Most of them spend more than half of their weekly income on paying for their boarding house rent. In fact, many residents are paying up to or even more than $110 per week for a small room in a boarding house, which often leaves them with $50 or less a week for all of their other expenses, including food and clothing.

Many of these residents are paying an amount for rent that is equal to the rent that they would be paying in share accommodation or for a house in many other parts of the country. The reasons that they are choosing to live in boarding houses are that they often cannot afford a bond, they do not have very good independent living skills and are unable to organise share accommodation, or quite often they are just unable to find anywhere at short notice. You will know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that vacancy rates in Sydney are very low and have been for some years.

There is no doubt that the government's position of making these most vulnerable residents pay a GST on their rents will increase the level of homelessness in this country. In fact, the government's own report into homelessness, the highly publicised National Homelessness Strategy, cites caravan park and boarding house residents as those most likely to slip into homelessness. Under this government's current proposal, these most vulnerable people, the ones identified by the government as the most vulnerable, are the only ones to be paying a GST on their rent.

This is in contrast, of course, with residential rents, which will be input taxed, and rents in aged or disability housing, which will be GST exempt. This inconsistent approach to residents in supported accommodation compared with those in caravan parks and boarding houses is ironic, because often the people who are living in caravan parks and boarding houses are there because they cannot find room in supported accommodation—which, of course, also should not be paying GST. The recently released Econtech report which the government has been sitting on since January shows that boarding house residents will definitely be worse off after 1 July. Rents will clearly go up by about 4.4 per cent compared with about 2.3 per cent in other types of housing. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Rural and Regional Australia: Regional Solutions Program

talk.start.para: —On 18 June, at the National Party's federal conference, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr John Anderson, announced the Regional Solutions Program. This program, which will provide $90 million over four years to regional and rural communities, is a well-targeted and innovative program. It recognises that rural communities do have the will, the drive and the initiative to achieve. But, of course, without the resources that are often evident in the major cities and major regional centres, they lack the necessary funds to seed self-help development opportunities. This is a commendable program and will act, I believe, as a potential circuit-breaker for many projects delayed by a lack of funding.

speech.para: Very significantly, the non-partisan Local Government Association of Queensland has issued a statement praising the initiative, stating that it `particularly commends the flexibility of the program'. The Executive Director of the LGA, Mr Greg Hallam, said:

quote.para: This is a timely initiative of the Federal Government which will be keenly supported across Queensland.

speech.para: The announcement of the program again underlines the continuing importance of the Regional Australia Summit last year and the recommendations that flowed from it. This is the summit which was derided by the Labor opposition in a rather foolish attempt to deny the fact that the National Party is the party of regional and rural Australians and is prepared to listen and act on their considered advice.

Under the program, grants will be available, for example, for community planning, local project implementation, community adjustment initiatives, regionally based enterprise or infrastructure projects and to employ community based development officers. A number of projects in my electorate that simply have not been able to find a home in any other grants scheme I believe would be applicable under this particular program. Some regrettably relate to training in some of the centres where there is a much higher level of unemployment.

This program is also going to complement the work of the Foundation for Rural and Regional Renewal, the establishment of which was announced at the summit. It also blends and integrates with other government initiatives such as the Rural Communities Program and the Rural Plan Initiative. Grants in the program can range up to $500,000—a not insignificant amount which underlines the practical nature of the program.

As I said, I am looking forward to going through the program and the application forms with all of the shire councils in my electorate. I firmly believe that it is going to be a flexible program that lends itself to rural communities. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I find myself in the position of having a few minutes somewhat unexpectedly, one of my colleagues apparently being otherwise occupied.
—I am sure you will do it very well.

—Thank you very much. On the fringe of my electorate in the suburb of Maribyrnong, which is, in fact, in the electorate of the member for Gellibrand, there is a very large parcel of land. For many years now—in fact, since the early part of the 20th century—it has been used by defence industry. The Maribyrnong complex is an area that was developed, as I understand it, prior to the First World War for Australia's defence industries. Over a number of years, those industries have tended to move off that site so that, in the foreseeable future, the whole of the site will become available for alternative uses. Many generations of people in my electorate have worked in that area. It is an area that not only attracts a lot of heritage interest but also has great historic significance to Australia—not just for general defence industry purposes but because, during the First World War, it was the staging depot for the Light Horse. In fact, thousands of Australian horses that went overseas, particularly to the Middle East, came from that depot on the banks of the Maribyrnong River.

speech.para: As the defence department develops its plans over the next year or so for the utilisation of this area, presumably primarily for residential purposes, it needs to very carefully take account of the heritage values of the area and ensure that they are respected. As I have said, it is a very important area from the point of view of Australian history, particularly Australian military history. In fact, on the site is the grave of what I understand to be the only Australian horse—a horse called Sandy—to return from the Middle East at the end of the First World War. The others were apparently not repatriated to Australia.

This is a subject that is immensely important to the Department of Defence in developing its plans for the utilisation of this site. It must ensure that fitting memorials and heritage symbols are located in the context of any development of the site. My colleague the member for Gellibrand and I will be keeping a very close eye on the development of the Department of Defence's plans for this site to ensure that the historical significance and importance of this area is adequately reflected in the final utilisation of the area.

subdebateinfo.title: Townsville: International Tropical Marine Science Centre

talk.start.para: —I would like to acquaint the Main Committee with the concept for an international tropical marine science centre in Townsville. The United Nations and other international agencies are charged with assisting communities of developing countries in the Indo-Pacific with sustainable development and conservation of marine and coastal resources, especially coral reefs, mangrove forests and seagrass beds. However, many of these agencies operate in isolation from each other, remote from sources of the latest scientific and management advice and remote from the communities they are assisting.

speech.para: The objective of this proposal is to establish a base for international agencies from which they can implement their project activities and develop new collaborative projects to arrest the decline in the world's marine resources and subsequent negative impacts on tropical coastal communities. The advantages of an international tropical marine centre in Townsville would be that it would be a hub of activity in the tropical Indo-Pacific region and bring many agencies involved in marine and coastal resource management in the Indo-Pacific tropics under one roof to create a greater mass of expertise and experience. It would also assist international agencies to fulfil their mandates in capacity building, integrated coastal management, research, policy formulation, sustainable development and outreach to small island developing states and to other tropical developing countries of the Indo-Pacific region. It will provide an environment whereby cooperation and collaboration are fostered to achieve maximum benefit from financial, logistic and personal resources.

The advantages of Townsville as a location for the centre would certainly be counted among these. Townsville is at the centre of the Indo-Pacific region, with an unrivalled concentration of expertise in tropical coastal areas, including coral reef research, management, teaching and administration capacity. It is adjacent to extensive areas of coral reefs, mangrove forests, seagrass beds and both soft bottomed and semi-hard bottomed benthic habitats. Townsville is a regional centre for North Queensland—in fact, the `capital city' of Northern Australia—with offices of local, state and national government as well as most resources required for such an international centre. It is serviced by efficient airline, rail and bus networks, with easy access to international travel either through Cairns or Brisbane. Townsville is serviced by efficient communications systems and has excellent conference facilities for small or large meetings.

I am strongly supportive of the concept of establishing an international tropical marine centre in Townsville to build on the great mass that is there already, with James Cook University, the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—Order! In accordance with standing order 275A the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed from 21 June.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Transport and Regional Services

quote.para: Proposed expenditure $508,145,000.

talk.start.para: —I would like once again to raise the plight of residents of the inner west suffering from aircraft noise from Sydney airport. I am pleased the minister is here this morning, because he would be aware of the numerous speeches I have made on this topic since I was elected to parliament and the numerous questions I have been asking him. I thank the minister for the most recent answers he has given to my questions in relation to the long-term operating plan, the PRM system and also the TAAATS.

speech.para: I am very concerned about the reports that I have been reading in the media in relation to the fact that the government seems to be not making any firm decisions about Badgerys Creek. The speculation is along the lines of, `We don't need Badgerys Creek in the short term; we will probably be able to run with the very fast train.' That is what has been reported in the media. I would like to give the minister the opportunity this morning, seeing that he is here, to respond to that because it is of great concern to the residents of my electorate of Lowe, and particularly to the residents of the inner west of Sydney.

When the Howard government came to power in 1996 they promised to make aircraft noise fairer and so the long-term operating plan was introduced. There has since been some fairness in some areas of Sydney in terms of a diminution in aircraft noise. However, in other areas, and particularly in my electorate to the north-west, they have been bombarded by aircraft noise. The reality is that we were promised we would have about 17 per cent of air traffic movements to the north, but the average is currently running at about 28 per cent, and that is clearly unacceptable.

This is directly relevant to taking the pressure off Sydney airport and making a decision on Badgerys Creek, because if the government does not make a decision on Badgerys Creek, my fear for my constituents in Lowe and for all the residents of the inner west is that we are going to get a further expansion of Sydney airport if, and God forbid, the government contemplates a fourth runway. Quite plainly, the people do not want it. The time has come for a statement to be made. The minister could help in this debate if he were able to indicate to us in the chamber today whether a decision will definitely be made to go ahead with Badgerys Creek.

Some of the speculation that I am getting fed, Minister, is that in the run-up to the election an announcement will be made to abandon Badgerys Creek for the moment and just run with the very fast train and the appropriate infrastructure that supports the very fast train. The speculation is that that, for the time being, will take the pressure off Kingsford Smith Airport, but if the government is re-elected then they will revisit Badgerys Creek. One does not want to be too cynical, but when I look around that area of Sydney and the federal seats of Macarthur, Parramatta, Lindsay and Macquarie, I can understand the politics of that decision.

It is a very, very serious issue. People are complaining to me. I have got a very large database in my electorate. About five per cent of the people in all the surveys that I have done think aircraft noise is the biggest issue, in some cases bigger than the GST. That might not come as a surprise to the minister because people just hear these big 747s flying over the roofs of their homes, particularly late at night, and that is very unacceptable. And whilst I know the introduction of the PRM system is designed to maximise flights in and out of Sydney airport in poor weather, there is a great fear that this system is going to be used at some future time to expand Sydney airport. That is in the forefront of people's minds, particularly in the lead-up to the election.

I would like to ask the minister, on behalf of my constituents and certainly the constituents of the inner west of Sydney, to allay those fears and give some guarantee that a decision will be made on Badgerys Creek before the next election. I have a question on the notice paper, as you know, Minister, asking whether a decision will be made before 1 September. From the intelligence I am hearing, a decision might be made by the government that will effectively mean that Badgerys Creek will be put back further. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —To facilitate proceedings I would like to raise a few issues relating to the matters raised by the member for Lowe so as to then give the minister the opportunity to deal with these issues all at once. Can I firstly say that I want to make it clear from the Labor Party's point of view that Kingsford Smith is here to stay. It is a major infrastructure development in Australia, and the real question is whether or not it is underutilised in this day and age.

speech.para: The real issues are how we more efficiently use Kingsford Smith and the status of the PRM inquiry. At what stage do we expect the trial to be completed? What will be the nature of the assessment and then the process for determining its potential implications for the more efficient use of Kingsford Smith? That is the crux of the PRM proposal. It comes back to not closing Kingsford Smith, and to how we as a nation more efficiently use the airport gateway to Australia. Having made very clear the Labor Party's point of view as to the future of Kingsford Smith, the objective is to more efficiently use Kingsford Smith. This goes to the potential outcome of the inquiry. I would also like advice from the minister as to any current proposals to require regional airlines to move from Kingsford Smith to Bankstown. If that is the case, what potential infrastructure proposals will be in place with respect to changes in road and rail transport? Building on that, it is obvious that there is now very strong consideration being given to a speed rail proposal, which is related to the potential better utilisation of Kingsford Smith. If a speed rail was actually put in place from Sydney to Canberra, and potentially to Melbourne, what implications does such a proposal have for freeing up slots for the purposes of the more efficient use of Kingsford Smith?

talk.start.para: —I would like to talk today about a major transport project in Dawson, the Burdekin bypass. This was announced in 1996. Since then the Department of Main Roads in Queensland have been undertaking consultation. I would like to bring to the House's attention, firstly, the reasons given by the consultants, Beard and Holland, for undertaking a bypass in that area. They looked at the amenity in the towns of Home Hill, Ayr and Brandon. Their final recommendation was that within 10 to 15 years time, particularly in Home Hill and Brandon, the safety and amenity in those towns would be severely compromised by the existing highway route. The other factor is that without a new alignment and new bridge there can be no reduction in accidents and, more seriously, fatalities. I do not believe that that report is one that any responsible member of parliament could ignore.

speech.para: I want to make a number of points plain. The consultation and planning is being undertaken by the state Department of Main Roads, obviously working closely with the federal Department of Transport and Regional Services. I find the statements to people in the community by the Premier that this is all federal are very unhelpful and somewhat dishonest. If I could talk about the process of public consultation, certainly initially there was a great deal of confusion about it. To be fair to the Department of Main Roads, they are now working very closely with the community. The public consultation and plans will be available throughout July and into August. That will give the local community an opportunity to look at the nine or prospectively 10 alignments being offered, to be able to see the pros and cons of each and to offer Department of Main Roads perhaps some alternatives. To the credit of the Department of Main Roads they have committed that any commonsense alternative or modification to an existing proposed alignment will be given consideration. The community there has certainly welcomed that.

There is, however, a dishonest campaign being run, partly by the state member there and others, that this could be cancelled and that we could simply put a line through the bypass. Indeed, that can be done. The reality, however, is that that would leave all of the farms and homes up there that are presently on one or other of the proposed alignments in an invidious position. They would never know whether they should build a house, put in an irrigation pump or be able to sell their farm. The value of their properties would be depressed because the bypass would always be an unknown factor in that area. Those calling for the bypass to be cancelled do not realise the difficulty that the community will incur if that is done.

I would like to talk about the priorities that I certainly have and which I know the federal minister shares in looking at the preferred option for the bypass. Obviously, the first one is to minimise impact on valuable farmland. The Burdekin is some of the richest agricultural land in Australia. Plainly, the towns depend on the farms for their livelihood. The bypass should also hug the towns to enable tourist traffic to go into the three towns there. It should relieve congestion, much of which is local congestion. Of the 9,000 vehicles a day, only 1,500 are through-traffic. Plainly, it should address the amenity in the towns, and safety.

One of the options that I believe fulfils those criteria is one that has yet to be examined fully by the Department of Main Roads—that is, the railway option, which follows the existing railway. There is a great deal of buffer land adjoining the railway. It is my belief, and that of many others in the community, including the chambers of commerce and some in the council, that following the railway line would minimise impact on agricultural land, generally keep to the towns, as the chambers of commerce wish, certainly reduce congestion, and obviously fulfil those requirements for amenity and safety. I emphasise that in the end this is a decision for the community. It is not one to be imposed upon the community. The broad consensus view of the Burdekin community after the public consultation will obviously be one that I will support. I have no doubt that the federal minister, when the state minister for transport makes a recommendation, will support that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have just spoken to my opposition colleagues. Before the Minister for Transport and Regional Services responds with respect to Sydney airport and the Bruce Highway, I would like to add a contribution on the Bruce Highway, which is of great concern to the member for Dawson and, dare I say, to the member for Capricornia and me, because it is the principal industry and tourism artery right up the east coast of Queensland. It carries a lot of traffic at all times and its safety needs to be paramount.

speech.para: Recently, the minister visited my area. He attended the opening of Rockhampton airport, which is in the electorate of the honourable member for Capricornia. It was a great day for Central Queensland. Afterwards, we flew to Gladstone and then drove down the Bruce Highway so that the minister could inspect various sections that have been finished. We inspected the Three Mile Creek Bridge in the Miriam Vale Shire, which was one of the low causeways that flooded many times. The minister and I then turned sods of soil at Colosseum Creek, where a new section of the highway will be straightened. A lot of up-hill and down-dale sections that were quite dangerous will be taken out. We then moved on to inspect the Tim Fischer Bridge, which was opened recently. It is a $24 million bridge which was necessitated by the Walla Weir. It was to be called the Wallaville Bridge, but to Tim Fischer's utter surprise, the state and federal ministers decided to name it in his honour.

We then went on to Childers, where another problem has arisen. The minister did not actually inspect them, but he was told about two areas there. One is the junction of the Bruce Highway and the Isis Highway at the town of Apple Tree Creek. This is a matter of great concern to the Isis Shire Council and, in particular, to its mayor, Bill Trevor, because at that junction the Bruce Highway, which carries the greater volume of traffic, has a very awkward junction with the Isis Highway which goes into Bundaberg. Three semitrailers have turned over there in the last month. It is a disaster waiting to happen. If it does not kill a truck driver, then certainly some other problem will happen, because this junction is at the bottom of a huge downhill grade. It only needs a miscalculation from someone coming off the Bruce Highway into the stream of the Isis Highway and we will have a real disaster. I note the minister has listed that for attention in subsequent budgets. I very much welcome that and thank him for it, but I would like to appeal to him today to give this the highest possible priority.

While he was at Childers the minister talked with Councillor Trevor about some passing lanes south of Childers. That was able to be funded out of the maintenance budget. That was where, again at the top of a hill, there should have been passing lanes rather than converging lanes, and that has also been attended to only in the last few weeks. Again, I thank the minister for that. It demonstrates that that area of the Bruce Highway between the Sunshine

A little further south, in the electorate of the member for Wide Bay, the Gunalda Range is a winding Coast and Rockhampton that is of great concern to all people in Central Queensland is receiving a great deal of attention.range where there have been lots of accidents. I have been there in a flood with water cascading over the road. It was one of the most frightening experiences I have had, with rocks coming down in the water. You have to drive along the highway with a virtual waterfall coming over the top of you. I have been there when a car has gone over that range and I have been there when a semitrailer has gone over it, so it must be very prone to accidents. I and all the members of Central Queensland welcome the upgrade of that highway.

In thanking the minister, I would particularly like to ask him if he would give the highest possible priority to that junction of the Bruce Highway and the Isis Highway and, a little further down the track when that is fixed, to give more attention to the two entries to Gladstone—the one at Benaraby and the one at Calliope.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this opportunity to seek details of the minister's present thinking in relation to the longer-term future of the Essendon airport in Melbourne. Essendon airport is an airport that has over many years provided service to Melbourne but, with the development of the Tullamarine Airport, local residents—my constituents and those of the member for Wills in particular—who are close to that airport have increasing concerns about the safety of the airport's operation, given its juxtaposition to residential areas.

speech.para: There have been a number of tragedies over the years involving the airport. For example, in the late 1970s a light aircraft crashed into a house in my electorate and killed a number of occupants. In fact, it virtually wiped out a family. In the 1980s an air ambulance crashed north of the airport, killing the occupants of that plane. Early in the 1990s a plane came down in my electorate. Miraculously, no-one was killed, but it took the roofs off a number of houses. Against this backdrop, the operational aspects of the airport and the safety for surrounding residents continue to be very much a matter of great concern to my constituents and those of the member for Wills who are in close proximity to the airport. It would seem to me that it is not a sustainable proposition into the longer term and it would be very useful in this context to get the minister's present thinking about it.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —In fairness to my colleague and opposite number, the member for Batman, he and I agreed that I would deal with airport issues and then he would seek to expand on other areas. That has become a little unravelled, but let me make some comments anyway and I am aware that the shadow minister will want to then raise certain further issues.

speech.para: Firstly, to come to the member for Lowe, let me say at the outset that I do appreciate very much that the question of lifestyle and the impact of aircraft noise on that lifestyle for very many Sydney residents is a live and real issue. We are committed to doing what we can to spreading, if you like, in an equitable way the impact of that real problem of aircraft noise in a way that ensures that people have as much respite as possible within a framework of reasonable sharing.

We attempt to do that under the LTOP—or the long-term operating plan—and under that the very contentious issue has been the proportion of take-offs and landings that are conducted to the north. It is worth noting, with all due respect to the member for Lowe, that we have reduced the average number of landings over the north of the airport from around 8,000 a month prior to us winning government in 1996 to an average of 4,200 a month over the past year, which is a 45 per cent reduction. With regard to more recent figures, the LTOP target is 17 per cent to the north. In 1999 the average was 27.2 per cent. In January of this year, it rose to 28.7 per cent. It is now trending down again on the figures that I have here. A new noise sharing mode, mode 8, was introduced in late December of 1999, but weather conditions have not permitted its extended use to date.

There is no doubt that we do face problems at Sydney airport with weather interrupting the effective operation of LTOP to a degree that I am somewhat concerned about. You will appreciate that, in terms of the safety of the airport, there are a lot of factors that have to be taken into account, not least of all switching modes on a frequent basis, particularly if the weather circumstances are uncertain. That can involve procedures that put quite a bit of stress on operators. I do not think any of us would ever want to suggest that they be compromised in their capacity to handle things efficiently and safely.

I repeat that it is a matter of ongoing interest for me and a source of some frustration that the targets are not more easily achieved. In fairness to Airservices—and I talk to them quite regularly about it—I am convinced, as a general rule of thumb, that they consistently seek to ensure proper safety and they aim for those targets to the best of their ability.

You asked about the decision on the airport. In the words of one of your own former greats, John Kerin, `Never believe what you read in the newspapers, old chap.' That is what he said to me in the House once when I attributed to him an intended course of action that had been outlined in the newspapers. We will be making decisions and they will not be far away. I cannot give a final deadline on those. I am the minister responsible, but these will be cabinet decisions. Cabinets always have an enormous agenda before them. I will be returning to cabinet as soon as we have finalised some details in relation to some of the difficult options that are before us. (Extension of time granted)

One of those options is this. We have spent quite a bit of time coming to the member for Batman's question. We do want to have a look at the impact of a high speed train were it to happen. I cannot give you a hard and fast answer. We have got all sorts of complicated formulas demonstrating what sort of difference it would make. If you believe some of the wilder claims, it buys three or four years. The realistic figure is probably 18 months to two years. But it does depend very heavily on factors such as the take-up or the usage of the high speed train, substitution for air traffic and the types of planes that are used out of places like Canberra. For that matter, the efficiency levels at Sydney airport are also quite closely related to the number of 767s versus 737s and the frequency of flights between places like Sydney and Melbourne. So there are an incredible number of factors there.

I would remind people that, in the interests of pursuing those questions of amenity and lifestyle problems in Sydney's inner suburbs—you have got some 900,000 people within the immediate radius of the airport who are affected by noise—we do have in place a cap on aircraft movements of 80 movements an hour. That is legislated. We are seeking to ensure that people have—and I think this is the best way of looking at it, to be honest—reasonable periods of respite from noise.

In terms of regional access to Sydney airport, I simply reiterate my position on this. Of course, I understand the concerns that rural and regional Australians have; I understand them well. I have ensured that those views are brought forward for proper consideration by cabinet. Indeed, I think it is true to say that people in regional New South Wales have an understandable view of Sydney that, after Sydneysiders, it is their city. They have a prior claim on it ahead of those from interstate or overseas—for education, health, business and tourism reasons. I think that is a fairly passionately held view out there.
