I was asked about PRM. The situation is that, between July and August this year, there will be a trial. A consultative committee will be set up to assist in the development, running and analysis of the trial that has been announced by Senator Hill. He will then report back to me with advice on whether or not PRM should be available for regular use. In terms of aircraft efficiency, in general terms, this is a debate about using the airport efficiently in bad weather. Anyone who has flown into Sydney knows that the delays can be quite significant in bad weather. PRM—precision radar monitoring—allows for the relief of congestion in bad weather in particular, by bringing the planes in on a more sophisticated landing basis, using technology that is currently not used at Sydney airport. The concern is that, in order to lock in, so to speak, on the signals that PRM is basically using, aircraft approaching from the north would come in earlier and lower, with certain implications for noise than would otherwise be the case. There are residents to the north who are concerned about that.

Again, in terms of efficiency, there is a cap of a maximum of 80 movements an hour. This would mean that you would be able to keep it flowing more freely in bad weather. That leads me to make another general comment. There is a lot of speculation about how we will or will not handle aircraft movements over the period of the Olympics. We believe that we are well placed to handle it. Certainly, I do not anticipate any problems at all in the build-up to the Olympics, when people will come in over a staggered period of time. The only circumstances in which I think we may face some difficulties is if we have very bad weather when the Olympics end and huge numbers of people want to leave in a very short time frame.

I noted what the members for Dawson and Hinkler had to say. In both cases, I am sure we can continue to work cooperatively with the resources we have. I noted some concerns about the Main Roads authority in Queensland. I can assure you that, compared to some of the problems we have had with the RTA and its costings in New South Wales, they are an absolute model of good performance. (Extension of time granted)

In relation to Essendon, the Minister for Finance and Administration has a real interest in this matter, as do I. We are approaching the matter again for re-examination, so the question is timely. There are some competing interests here which would produce different outcomes. We are trying to take into account the views that are put to us. There are the views of members here; there are also the views of country Victorians who are adamant that they need it for health services and other charter operations. I have nothing to add except that we will take those into account properly when we consider whether or not it is best sold as real estate or as a going concern.

talk.start.para: —I have a couple of aviation related issues. Firstly, I seek clarification from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services with respect to the potential sale of Essendon; whether the department, in association with the Minister for Finance and Administration, has actively given consideration to changing the conditions of sale on this occasion, whereas on the previous occasion the conditions of sale related to the airport being sold only on the basis that it would continue to operate as an airport.

speech.para: Secondly, I go to the proposal concerning the operation of the ACCC and its funding and the budget's suggestion that the aviation industry should make a contribution through a levy for the purposes of funding the ACCC. I notice in the budget announcements that, for telecommunications and postal services, the government announced a levy on Telstra and Australia Post—that is, the suppliers of the services the subject of the ACCC prices monitoring. As the airports are, in essence, the suppliers of the services which are subject to the ACCC monitoring, I would like an explanation as to why the airports, the suppliers of the services and the organisations that in the past have demonstrated, I might say, a capacity to engage in arguably monopolistic pricing and got off scot-free, do not have a levy placed on them, as against potentially on the airlines? I think the Australian public is entitled to an explanation concerning these issues.

talk.start.para: —Can I ask you to repeat that question?

—What I am referring to is the question of the imposition of the levy for the purposes of funding the ACCC. Why has it been imposed on the airlines and not on the operators at the airports? As part and parcel of that, is it also fair to suggest that this levy, if it goes through, because of higher than expected airline activity and increased fuel usage, will simply result in increased levy collections and provide a windfall to the government?

speech.para: On the question of aeronautical charges, I go to the issue of the Sydney Airport Corporation. From what I understand, SACL has now withdrawn its proposed increase in aeronautical charges, which amounted to about 130 per cent; that, if anything, those proposed increases in charges may potentially be in disarray; and that SACL has advised the ACCC of that. I understand from the feedback I have received that one of the questions being pursued in association with the potential determination of SACL charges is the value of existing land at Sydney airport for the purposes of setting aeronautical charges and the view of the airline operators that the value of the land, as such, should be zero. As I think it is accepted on both sides of the House that Sydney airport is here to stay forever and a day for the purposes of aviation operation, is it the minister's view that, for the purposes of considering potential price increases, the value of existing land at Sydney airport for the purposes of Sydney aeronautical charges should be zero?

I now go to problems concerning the issue of the noise levy. Firstly, with respect to its implementation in areas in and around the Sydney airport, is it true that there are difficulties relating to the administration of this scheme? For example, is it true that there are allegations of landlords of properties that have been insulated and airconditioned under the scheme ripping out the airconditioning system for use in their own homes? If that is the case, has the government initiated an inquiry into these potential rorts; and, if so, what has been the outcome of such an inquiry? If not, what is the government going to do about it?

That also takes me to the extension of the noise levy to the operation of Adelaide airport. On what basis did the government simply extend the same levy that operates at Sydney airport for the purposes of overcoming the noise difficulties at Adelaide airport? Is it true, for example, that, potentially, proper consideration was not given to whether or not the $3.40 collected from passengers falls well short of the actual levy payment to the government, because the amount payable by airlines is determined by a complex formula that accounts for aircraft size, weight, passenger configuration and engine type? Is it also therefore appropriate that the amount of the Sydney levy needs revisiting rather than just dumping it on Adelaide? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am heartened that the minister is committed to sharing and spreading the noise from Kingsford Smith airport. I will acknowledge the point he made that there was a reduction in aircraft noise with the opening of the east-west runway. There was a concentration with the operation of the parallel runways before the Howard government came in in 1996.

speech.para: My concern is with the long-term operating plan, which the government promised the people of Sydney in 1996 would give fair and equitable relief from aircraft noise. The long-term operating plan, as the minister knows, was introduced in August 1997. Whilst it has done a lot to spread aircraft noise, the reality for the people in the inner west and particularly in my electorate of Lowe is that we were given an expectation that there would be 17 per cent of air traffic movements to the north, and effectively it has remained almost double since August 1997. Even now, although the minister says it is trending down, it is only trending down by a little over one percentage point. Sure, the weather is a factor, and no-one will ever question safety. I seriously want to question the minister as to whether the long-term operating plan can ever be fully implemented, particularly as it relates to my constituents in Lowe.

The minister mentioned that he talks to Airservices Australia regularly. I am blue in the face with passing resolutions unanimously at the Sydney Airport Community Forum. I will give a plug to Dr Brendan Nelson, the member for Bradfield, who chairs that, for his resolve to have Airservices Australia fully implement that plan. But the feeling of the Sydney Airport Community Forum is almost one of impotence that Airservices Australia—and you are responsible for them, Minister—are not working hard enough. They might not be working hard enough if safety is such a factor that the long-term operating plan can never be introduced.

Can I remind you of your own words in a reply to a question that I put to you on notice on 6 April and to which you replied on 14 June. The question that I put to you was: when will the long-term operating plan be fully implemented? The reply that I received from you was:

quote.para: LTOP is being progressively implemented ...

speech.para: That is true, it is. It went on:

quote.para: Almost all elements of the Plan have now been put in place. I am advised that Airservices Australia informed the 24th meeting of the Sydney Airport Community Forum that the outstanding elements of the Plan involve technically difficult operations which will require extensive training and will add to the complexity of human management aspects of airport operations. The Forum was also informed by Airservices Australia that while these outstanding elements will not assist in achieving the LTOP runway and movement targets they will alleviate the concentration of overflights over certain areas.

speech.para: My reading of that is not inconsistent with what you have said today. But against the background that, when the government came in in 1996 and gave an expectation to the residents of Sydney—particularly those in the inner west who have suffered the most—that we would get a fairer distribution of aircraft noise, I hold the view, and I would like you to demolish it, that we are not going to see the long-term operating plan implemented as envisaged—that is, 17 per cent of movements to the north over my electorate in the inner west—in the foreseeable future.

If it is not the technically difficult operations that you refer to, and the requirement for extensive training and the complexity of the human management aspects of airport operations, then I suspect that when that is superimposed on the safety issue there is not going to be any dramatic change to that target level. It is certainly not going to happen in the next few months with the introduction of PRM and the Olympics and the amount of traffic that is coming in and out of Sydney. Against the background that you do speak of Airservices Australia very regularly, what can you do to make them fully implement that plan as soon as possible? (Time expired)

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Lowe for his concerns. I do not think I can add anything to what I have already said, except to say in good faith that I will talk to Airservices again—I do it frequently. Bill Pollard is overseas at the moment but I will talk to them again in the context of having your very pointed question in front of me at the time. I recognise people's interest in this and, again, I point to the fact that there has been a real improvement in the situation. Perhaps people ought to think most usefully of it in terms of respite time. Let me acknowledge the obvious, too: finding durable long-term solutions to the needs of the Sydney basin airport is a critical part of a long-term solution to these issues.

speech.para: Let me come very briefly to the issues raised by the shadow minister. As you know, Sydney airport is still owned by the government. Its operational aspects and financial matters are oversighted by the Minister for Finance and Administration. You have alluded to the fact that they are in the process at the moment of reviewing their pricing arrangements. They are mounting a spirited case that, firstly, SACL and its shareholders have not been receiving a fair return on investment and, secondly, they are left in a position where they cannot adequately upgrade their infrastructure.

This is a draft proposal. I concede that I have some concerns about it but I do not think it is fair for me to canvass those concerns here. In part they go to the question of evaluation of land and whether it is appropriate for SACL to be asking for a return on that land in the current circumstances. But beyond confirming that I have worked the issue through to some extent with the minister for finance and that I receive regular representations on the matter—which will not surprise you—I again stress that this is a draft. It will have to be worked through and produce a fair outcome for SACL and its shareholders—and that means the government too. We all need to be able to see that there is an appropriate return and the capacity to invest in the future.

As you said, on the other hand it is an incredibly important gateway to Australia. Roughly as many people fly into Sydney airport as fly into Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth combined. Its usage is extraordinary, and it keeps rising. In physical terms it is not a terribly big airport. It is only a bit over 900 hectares and there are all sorts of constraints on its use, not least that legislated cap on aircraft movements.

I point out that under the proposed new access charges there would not be an increase in aeronautical charges for regional aircraft that weigh less than 10 tonnes. Those that are over that may cop a very small increase on a one-way fare of less than $1. Again it is worth pointing out that people should keep a sense of calm and perspective about this. The impact of the proposed changes on a one-way fare from Sydney to London is not as high as some would have you believe. Nonetheless, it is a sensitive issue and it will have to be worked through. If you want me to pursue a more detailed response from the minister for finance I am happy to do so but, given the demands on my time, I will do that only if you ask for it.

Again, I confirm there have been administrative problems with insulation from time to time but I am not aware of anything going on currently. I will have a look, but I have not been advised that we have got a particular problem at this point in time. So far we have managed to work through such problems as we have had over the years pretty constructively. The program is very much appreciated—there is no doubt about that—by those who have benefited from it. I can confirm that we are even adjusting allowances to cover the cost of the increased insulation from 1 July for affected houses. We have even been detailed enough to get down to the level of the increased cost of insulation for weatherboard houses that require insulation of the walls. It is quite a comprehensive program. (Extension of time granted)

The way the levy basically works is that we determine what is going to be needed and the airlines are responsible for raising that money. In the case, for example, of Sydney, the airlines have chosen not to impose a levy on the Sydney-Canberra link for a number of reasons, and that is their right. We simply require that they go about raising the funds and we leave it to them to determine a fair and reasonable way to do it.

I will come to a couple of the other issues that have been raised. I am getting a bit of a backlog here. I probably ought to say something about the Burdekin bypass. This has been a very long and ongoing issue. The member for Dawson has been very concerned, indeed, that the right outcome for the community is struck here. I know from personal experience how hard these issues can be. You have communities where the traffic snarl just becomes unmanageable and the community needs a bypass of some sort but, when you actually start to look at the options, it is almost impossible to find one that does not have an adverse impact and, legitimately, people complain.

I understand that the recommendation by the state minister on the preferred alignment is likely to be made in September or October of this year. I will look at that very carefully indeed to ensure that it has the broadest possible community support; that it has a minimal impact on the very valuable farmland, which is the particular issue here—a beautiful belt of country; that it utilises existing corridors such as minor roads as far as possible; that it relieves congestion; and that it works well for the local community. It is, of course, largely a matter for the DMR and for the state minister because they are responsible. This is the way we do it in every state on the national highway grid. They are responsible for the consultation phases and the design phases, reaching community agreement and then moving through such matters as the EISs. So it is very much the responsibility of the state member for Burdekin to raise matters regarding consultation and planning with the state minister, Mr Bredhauer. He can pursue that through the parliament or whatever. But we will fund the work. We will make certain that the final recommendation is appropriate before we fund that, of course, so it will have to be quality work and worked through the community properly. The member, De-Anne Kelly, keeps me very well informed. As always, we will try and make certain we get the right outcome.

While I am on the subject of roads, I should confirm that the biggest infrastructure project governments have been engaged in since the Snowy Mountains scheme is the upgrading of the Pacific Highway, which is being done as a RONI—roads of national importance—project between the Commonwealth and the state, a $3 billion project. I can confirm not only continued funding for that but also John Sharp's and Mark Vaile's commitment that the Kempsey and Macksville bypasses will have priority in the second five-year stage of the new Pacific Highway. I think that about wraps it up. You rapid fire on these things and you cover them as best you can, but you will raise them again, I am sure, if I have missed something.

talk.start.para: —I am taking the debate back to the airports area. I sympathise with the member for Lowe and the comments that he has raised this morning about having too many aircraft going over his electorate, but in my town of Rockhampton we want more aeroplanes, not fewer.
—You need a few firefighters there.

—Yes, funny you should mention that. On that issue, I want to take this opportunity to advise the minister that the issue of our firefighting services at Rockhampton airport is still very much alive. In recent weeks I have had discussions with people from a number of interested groups. Specifically, one of our local tourism bodies have spoken to me about their concerns with the possible reduction in firefighting services and what that means for our ability to take international tourist flights. Also, I was at the Rockhampton Show for much of last week and a number of airport firefighters and their families came to see me about this. On an interesting note, one of our local firefighters was on centre stage at the Olympic torch relay—Kenrick Tucker, a former Olympian. He lit the community cauldron at that event a few nights ago. So our firefighters are certainly in the news.

speech.para: The issue that I am following as the local member is the effect of CASA's draft regulatory standards for aviation firefighting services. In particular, the problem that our local firefighting officers see is the proposal to base the level of firefighting services on annual passenger movements of 350,000 passengers. This is a change to the current criterion and one which would see a reduction to the level of services at Rockhampton airport and a consequent loss of firefighting jobs in our town.

I understand that the time for the feedback to CASA's draft regulations has now closed and, given that we are now at the stage of considering those draft regulations, I would like to ask the minister: what was the nature of the feedback on those draft regulations? Will there be a change to the draft standards as a result of the feedback from the aviation industry? Specifically, what is the likely future of the firefighting services at the Rockhampton airport, given the final outcome that is likely in terms of the passenger numbers required under the draft regulations to maintain our current level of firefighting services?

In previous speeches I have already been through the reasons why our local community sees the classification and capacity of our airport as important issues, and why the firefighting service is an integral part of the future that we want for our airport and our local community. I will not go into those issues now; I will leave those questions with the minister and I look forward to his reply.

talk.start.para: —Minister, I would like to raise two issues in the short time that I have, the first one dealing with CASA, and I have raised it publicly on a number of occasions. It is the lack of CASA personnel in the Darwin office to service the northern Australian region. This has a bearing, as you would be aware, Minister, on the operations of a number of very small charter operators around northern Australia, and on the operations of those involved in running scheduled services.

speech.para: What has come to my notice is that the failure of CASA to have enough resources in the Darwin office has meant a great cost to some of these operators where they have been unable to get aircraft added to their operator's certificate because of the inability of CASA to come and do the inspections. They have had great difficulty. In one instance, a chief pilot was to be tested by CASA. Had CASA not arrived on this particular Wednesday the operators would have been off the air; they would not have been able to fly. They had been making requests for some months. CASA's staff in Darwin were aware of it, but they are so under-resourced that they are unable to carry out their functions in a way which deals appropriately with the demands placed upon them by those flying aircraft around northern Australia.

Minister, this is a sincere request that we do something about ensuring that CASA has sufficient resources so that people are not penalised because of where they live. Unfortunately, the fact is that these people are being penalised, and some of the people who are being penalised live in isolated Aboriginal communities. Two particular instances that I am aware of in north-east Arnhem Land involved Aboriginal-owned aircraft operators. One nearly had their licence cancelled because of the inability of CASA to do the work. That happened only three weeks ago. As I say, this is a sincere request, Mr Deputy Speaker, for the minister to try to inform us as to how CASA intends to ensure that sufficient staff resources and other resources that may be required are made available to the Darwin office.

The other issue I want to raise, Mr Deputy Speaker, through you to the minister, is fuel prices. There are great political diatribes—from both sides of the parliament, I might say—about the issue of fuel prices, but the reality is, Minister, that people in my electorate are burdened with unreasonably high fuel prices. I have here a list of the fuel prices for a number of places up and down the Stuart Highway. These prices were effective on Friday, 16 June. I will go through them very quickly to give you an indication of what people are paying for fuel along the Stuart Highway: Dunmarra, 112c; Elliott, 111.9c; Renner Springs, 114.9c; and Barrow Creek, 117.9c. These are unreasonable prices. I rang the ACCC and asked them if they could undertake an inquiry into fuel prices in the Northern Territory. They said that they needed a reference from the Minister for Finance and Administration. I wrote to the minister for finance; he responded by saying that he would not be prepared to provide the reference to the ACCC.
A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 10.57 a.m. to 11.08 a.m.

talk.start.para: —As I was saying, I have written to the minister for finance and asked him if he would refer the matter to the ACCC. He has refused. The point I want to make to the minister, who has not yet returned from the House after the division, is that it is unreasonable for people in the Northern Territory to be expected to pay these prices for fuel. Indeed, in some places, fuel prices are as high as $1.60 per litre. What I want to know is whether, as a result of the Fuel Sales Grants Bill, these fuel prices will go down or whether they will increase. What we know of the government's proposal so far, in the formula they have provided, is that each one of those prices would increase substantially. That is an unfair and an unreasonable burden. I ask the minister to ensure that this does not take place and I also ask him to approach the minister for finance and ensure that there is a reference to the ACCC for an inquiry into fuel prices in the Northern Territory.

—I will make a few comments whilst we wait for the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, who is burdened with the problems of the National Party at the moment and finding it hard to find his way back to the Main Committee. I have already specifically raised the issue of coastal shipping. I note that, even yesterday, there have been increased penalties for airlines carrying illegal immigrants. For example, from 1 July infringement penalties increase from $3,000 to $5,000. This is of great importance to the airline industry because of the difficulties we have with illegal immigrants. In that context I also note, as I raised in the House of Representatives recently, the fact that between March 1996 and April 1999, 263 foreign seafarers jumped ship in Australia, of which only 148 were located.

speech.para: As each airline pays a levy of $5,000 per illegal entry, from my knowledge of the portfolio it has been suggested that shipowners and operators do not pay anything as a result of these people jumping ship. I think—and I will end on this point for the purposes of facilitating other portfolios—the Australian public needs to know why the government is not holding foreign shipowners and operators more accountable for the financial implications of ship jumpers. What is the government going to do to recoup from owners and operators of ships the costs of actually pursuing some of these people who jump ship in the same way in which airlines are pursued on a regular basis, with fines for airlines being increased from 1 July this year?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: —Let me very briefly come to this issue raised by the member for Batman a moment ago in relation to coastal shipping and claims by him that the number of illegal immigrants has jumped with the increased number of single voyage permits. The figures are actually, as a proportion of the problem we have with illegal immigration in this country, not very high. It is actually stretching the case to make out that there is a significant leap as a result of the increase of single voyage permits, and this smacks of an MUA perspective on life.
—They are department of immigration figures.

—The figures maybe, but you are linking them to the increased number of single voyage permits and trying to make out that there is some exploding crisis here. The MUA's position on this does not really stack up. But I can say to you—and I am not going to go beyond this; you have raised it in the House—that I am exploring the matter of the government's strengthened approach to the problem of illegal immigration.

speech.para: In returning to fuel prices in the Northern Territory, yes, fuel prices are a very real problem in far-flung parts of this country. I know that city consumers do not like paying the sorts of prices they are seeing at the moment. But compared with the volume of fuel used by rural and regional Australians in remote areas, it is a relatively insignificant problem. In a city like Sydney or Melbourne, the price is still cheap by, say, European standards and the mileage is not so vastly different.

talk.start.para: —I said `by comparison'. But when you look at what happens in rural and regional and remote areas of the sort that your colleague from the Northern Territory raised, it becomes a real issue. Many people in far-flung parts of the country, for a start, have to travel vast distances. Secondly, you cannot do it in a Hyundai. There a lot of people in this country—in practical terms, I am one of them—who have to drive a heavy four-wheel drive. Even in my own home village, just filling up a Toyota Landcruiser station wagon the other day cost me $121.50. It is a real issue. What will not make good copy for the ALP at the next election is Mr Beattie's antics, where he sought recently to engage in a little political opportunism which would have seen a massive discrimination against far-flung—
—What about the ACCC's interest in the Northern Territory? Answer the question.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, you always know when the ALP wants to get you off something that is a bit hot. You see it in the main chamber; you see it up here. The minute we start to make a point that embarrasses them a bit they are up there with one point of order followed by another point of order and then another point of order, and we end up seeing who can shout the loudest. There is no doubt about you.

speech.para: The point that needs to be clearly established here is that what Mr Beattie tried to do was to engage in a little endeavour which would have cost rural and regional Queenslanders—the more remote they were, the greater the discrimination—a lot of money. A $150 refund is all right if you are only doing 15,000 kilometres a year in a four-cylinder car. It is one tank of fuel for somebody in remote Queensland.

talk.start.para: —If you use more than 40 litres, you're finished.

—That is right. As Mr Beattie acknowledged only a few years ago, it was going to cost the average Queensland family up to $400. But guess who it was going to cost even more? Those in remote areas. On this rare occasion I find myself in a fair degree of sympathy with the member for the Northern Territory. It is a problem. None of us like to see rises in crude oil prices and none of us like to see people in far-flung regions disadvantaged. Unfortunately, because prices for crude were too low for too long globally, exploration started to dry up, development and refining capacity were not expanded, and the inevitable result was that the solution to low prices was low prices—as we say in the bush, Wilson. And this time, unfortunately, we are the ones who pay the price as fuel consumers. Wherever there is exploitation and evidence of exploitation, the government is prepared to seek to right the situation. I am absolutely confident that if the relevant minister is determined that there is no basis for an ACCC inquiry, that is appropriate.(Extension of time granted).

speech.para: I do not know that I have much more to add there, except to say that it ought to be remembered that in just a few days time, one of the great problems faced in rural and regional Australia, that of excessive government taxation on transport, will be massively addressed. It has never been addressed before by a government in this place—certainly not addressed to the extent that we have put in place.

talk.start.para: —It is a hoax.

—A hoax? So the complete abolition of fuel excise on rail is a hoax? So the reduction in the effective cost of excise on heavy haulage diesel from 44c to 20c a litre is a hoax. I think that really displays the intelligentsia of the ALP at their very finest.

speech.para: I was asked about CASA's capacity to meet demands in northern Australia. I can only say that we are doing our best to ensure that CASA is devoting sufficient resources, particularly in the area of surveillance, to those areas that will secure the best possible safety outcomes. We are all, I know, very sensitive to this issue of safety. I note that I am often lobbied by communities, and usually in very sensible terms by members as well on their behalf, about air services in remote parts of the country. We all need to be mindful, however, that there can be no compromising on issues of safety.

talk.start.para: —Why don't you release Barry Wakelin's letters?

—I could release a couple of letters from the member for the Northern Territory, I suppose. This may be of some interest to members: I can indicate that a while before the Whyalla crash, as a matter of fact, I had one of my regular meetings with the chairman of CASA and the director of civil aviation. I made a couple of points that I think are very important and which I have now revealed publicly; that is, that CASA are in a financial position—thanks to certain actions that I took which were promptly criticised by one or two experts around the country but which I think were needed—and have been for some time, to ensure that they have the capacity to devote the resources they need to critical areas of surveillance.

speech.para: I have said that CASA must ensure that they have quality people and reward them appropriately. They ought to be very firm indeed on people who are not performing, but they ought to properly reward those who are, and they must ensure, with the new entrants into the aviation market in this country—Impulse and Virgin—that the extra aeroplanes that have to be monitored are not allowed in any way to diminish their surveillance. They are getting their surveillance levels in some critical areas up to much more satisfactory levels in the last 12 months, reflecting effective driving from the top at CASA.

Having said that, I am not going to run away from the fact that we have got a long way still to go with CASA. I think we are making reasonable progress. In terms of having the people we need on the ground in these far-flung regions, reflecting a concern about the minister, I will have a look at how we are getting on with our attempts to ensure that we are addressing some of these needs in far-flung regions. It has been raised with me quite a few times. We have taken certain actions—for example, we have substantially increased the remote air service subsidy scheme, which is very important to people in remote areas because often those small services are of such critical importance to them. It is hard for us in a city like Canberra to have any consciousness at all of just how their lifestyles and economic opportunities are compromised if they do not have those services operating. We are doing what we can. We will not compromise on safety.

I have set up an advisory board for CASA made up of people outside and put a prominent Northern Territorian on it. He has that unique capacity of Territorians to express himself in very robust terms. I have not heard him use the term spade yet. I think he will make a very worthwhile contribution. We will keep doing what we can to get it right. In relation to Capricornia, you will have the services you need as you need them. I hope it is an international airport that functions fully one day too. We put the money in to make sure it was possible. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

quote.para: Proposed expenditure $407,565,000.

talk.start.para: —This particular budget expenditure relates to one of the most significant sectors in the Australian economy, one which is very important to the economic and social survival of rural and regional areas. There are going to be significant penalties imposed as a result of this budget in rural and regional areas. The Leader of the National Party and Deputy Prime Minister is leaving the chamber. He will be well aware of the angst in rural and regional Australia at the National Party and its failure to stand up to city based lawyers and stockbrokers in the Liberal Party in the formulation of budgets that are going to wreak significant pain and havoc in rural and regional Australia.

speech.para: I note from the recent ABARE Australian Farm Surveys Report 2000 that the gross value of agricultural production in Australia has been relatively stable over the past five years. That is due in no small part, as the report notes, to the increased diversity in agricultural production in rural and regional Australia. This is an area of the sector that governments need to address with greater effort.

I was in Beechworth last weekend at the ALP's country conference; the National Party were holding theirs with the white shoe brigade up on the Sunshine Coast. The ALP was out in rural Victoria, as it always is when it holds its country conferences. We hold them in rural and regional Australia. We are not afraid to put `country' back into our terminology, but I do notice that the National Party over time have taken `Country' out of the name of their political party.

As the National Party is in its final political death rattle out there in the electorate, we are quite amazed at the interjections that are coming to us here over this budget that is going to impose quite intolerable burdens on Australian farmers and their families. I note from this report that the terms of trade have moved against farmers during the 1990s, perhaps not to the extent that they did in the 1980s, but, with the ramping up of farm costs that will flow directly from this particular budget, we are going to see a further decline in the terms of trade of Australian farmers.

I want to home in on one aspect that lies behind this budget and this particular budget allocation in the Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry area. It is the impact of this budget on farm costs. What we know is that the Liberal Party members from rural areas and those National Party members left in rural areas—there are not many of them, but of course—
Mr Zahra interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is all right, my good friend the honourable member for McMillan; I quite enjoy the spirited interjections from those who will not be with us for too long in this parliament. I think we ought to let them indulge themselves for one last time because it is likely that this will be the last budget of the coalition as the penny drops in rural and regional Australia. The Prime Minister will go to the polls to cut his losses and, thankfully, when Australia's rural community faces its next budget, it will be in good hands. It will be in Labor hands and we will ensure that the sorts of things that are taking place in this budget do not take place. Implicit in this budget and the allocations that are made to agriculture, fisheries and forestry is a deliberate ramping up of the inflation rate as a result of the GST. (Time expired)

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Minister for Forestry and Conservation and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I found that a rather amazing contribution from the lead spokesman of the Labor Party. I would have thought that by now I would be subject to a list of financial items appearing in the budget that the shadow minister chose to criticise. Instead of that, we just got five minutes of rhetoric. Therefore, I think it appropriate for me to respond to the rhetoric immediately.

speech.para: The gravest fright that Australian rural people are getting now, particularly from my experience with forestry, is when a Labor member of parliament visits their area, because every time they turn up they lose something. We have had to go down to Eden in the last 48 hours to give people money to re-establish the businesses and the business activity that Bob Carr has taken away. I see the member for McMillan here and I have not heard a word from him. The union and various Liberal members have been in contact to tell me that the state government of Victoria has already welched on the deal it made to guarantee two years of wood resource to the sawmillers of the latest two Victorian RFAs in western Gippsland for the purpose of ensuring a reasonable transition. We have got NRE people going around Victoria, saying, `All that wood we promised you're not going to get. Our minister has told us we've got to put the screws on you now.'

That is black and white. I have been obliged to write to the minister in Victoria drawing her attention to the agreements we made to protect those workers' jobs so that the expenditure of this government—$20 million, as arranged in this program—and the expenditure of the state government can be used to ensure that jobs are not lost in a very difficult area. But what is the message they are getting from the Victorian Labor government? `Mate, jump ship now. We are going to be very tough on you in the future.' So everywhere a Labor MP turns up, the locals lose something. They do not gain anything; something is taken away. Carr does it daily throughout the regions of New South Wales. His own cabinet subcommittee made some recommendations on the southern region and then he sat down with a few of his greenie mates and drew some circles on a map and knocked people flat. We have to go back and repair the damage. That is the first thing.

Then isn't it nice to stand up in the federal parliament and say something about the impact of this budget on farm costs? Can the member for Corio ever tell us when a farmer got 10 per cent off his petrol bill? Can the member for Corio ever tell us when someone who has got substantial freight costs in grain was able to see a national average $2 a tonne reduction in grain freights? If you grow 5,000 tonnes of wheat, let me tell you that is $10,000. I have to tell you $10,000 because I think you and your leader are maths deficient. The fact of life is that your leader gets into all sorts of amazing arithmetical exercises, even telling us that all the profits of Telstra come to the Australian parliament when in fact all we get is half the dividends. Apparently your leader does not know the difference. Is the member for Corio going to tell us that farmers have always got sales tax off their farm truck or their petrol vehicles that they drive 70 per cent for business? Is the member for Corio going to stand up here and say this budget does not make those grants to people? It is just unbelievable. As I said, they are clearly maths deficient. I welcome the minister along to take over from me. He, of course, will be much more competent in rebutting these areas.

The whole situation is that everywhere Country Labor turn up, the local people lose something. We have had to go down to Eden as a first step. We have a wider policy, with $90 million now identified for this program where we get the local people to start to invest money for the purpose of creating real jobs that will last. We are not putting money into the jobs; we are putting money into the capital so the jobs will remain. Your programs would always pay the wages till the money ran out and the jobs ran out. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The government has curtailed debate on this committee process and that is a disgrace in itself. I will conclude my remarks on this reluctantly so that I can give some time to my comrades to make some points. Let me just make a few umbrella points about this particular aspect of the government's budget. We have seen over the time of the coalition the progressive cuts to AFFA personnel and to the AFFA budget. We see it again in this budget that has been presented to the parliament. One of the great failures of this budget is that it does not adequately address the infrastructure needs of rural and regional Australia and, of course, the long-term future of the sector is going to be underpinned by that infrastructure which has been progressively run down by the coalition.

speech.para: The great jewel in the coalition's crown, as far as the AFFA budget is concerned, is the AAA package. We all know where it came from—it was basically an amalgam of Labor programs and then marketed as AAA. Let me put on the public record that in the first four years I understand the package was worth $525 million. The government in extending the program have tried to portray this as new money, at $309 million over the next four years. They are claiming that there was a carryover element of some $100 million unspent from the previous allocation. But even when we add that in we see that the centrepiece of the government's program allocation to rural and regional Australia has actually declined.

The government also makes great play of the fact that it has allocated $22.3 million of funding for the national approach to animal and plant health. If you go behind the figures, some $700,000 of that belongs to the government, the other is administered funds. That means it comes from other sources and industry.

The really interesting one in this is the claim by the government that it is allocating $45 million for dairy regional assistance which is funded by a consumer levy. This has been the great deceit out there in rural Australia with regard to the dairy industry. The minister parades himself and says that the government is providing $1.7 billion. The dairy farmers know where that money is coming from. It is coming from consumers. It is a consumer transfer. They know out in rural and regional Australia that the $45 million comes from that source, and it is to be administered within the bowels of government. They know that there is not a lot of your money in the $1.7 billion package.

So as you strut around the country telling state governments to put money into the dairy industry, how about putting some in yourself? Do not go lecturing Labor state governments about what they ought to do in Queensland and New South Wales; put your own money in and then you will have some credible basis for bringing that sort of criticism to bear on the Labor Party.

I do not have time to go into the fuel hoax. When rural and regional Australia wakes up to the fact that neither fuel prices nor the prices they pay in their supermarkets and local stores are going to come cascading down, most of you will be finished. I welcome the honourable member who has just come into the chamber, Mr Anthony, because this will probably be his last presentation to the Main Committee as a member of the government. I will leave it to my colleagues here to outline some further aspects of this particular budget as it relates to rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —I have to take up the challenge issued to me by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation and demonstrate why it is not the case that, when a Labor MP turns up in a regional area, something closes. I have to tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that is not the case in my electorate. When you look at the Victorian state budget as it relates to my electoral district, you will understand the contrast between a government that is committed to a regional area and the federal government which is prepared to do absolutely nothing to help the lot of people who live in rural and regional Australia.

speech.para: Some of the things that have been committed to by the state Labor government include: $2 million to the Latrobe Valley for the development of an energy park—fantastic news; $11 million to the Latrobe Valley for the development of an education precinct; $4.9 million for the Newborough campus of the Central Gippsland Institute of TAFE; $1½ million for the development of the Grey Street primary school; $3½ million for the Warragul Regional College; and $5 million for the building of a new police station in Moe.

The Minister for Forestry and Conservation says that whenever a Labor MP turns up, something closes. The complete opposite is the case in my electorate. When Labor MPs and Labor ministers arrive, something gets funding, something gets support from the government, and money is invested in critical areas of infrastructure which we, as a community, depend upon.

I note that the Minister for Forestry and Conservation made some comments about the $3½ million which the federal government has provided to the Eden community in New South Wales as a result of the closure of the cannery there. The situation in Eden demonstrates the absolutely debauched stage that the funding for regional development has got to under this government. They give $3½ million to the Eden community for the loss of 150 jobs, but in Drouin, a community of just 4,000 people, where the Bonlac butter factory has closed with the loss of 170 jobs, we have seen nothing at all from the federal government to help that community get over that enormous shock, despite the enormous amount of activity which has come from the Victorian state Labor government to try to get Drouin back on its feet, to try to get it doing something to compensate for the loss of jobs.

So when the minister starts parading this fantastic achievement of $3½ million for Eden, what he is not saying is that they are playing favourites. They are picking where the money can go, not by any sort of fair process but by picking out where they want the money to go, based on where they need to prop up members in marginal seats. The Drouin community deserve better than that. They deserve a fair process. The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, who is at the table, should explain that no federal government money has come to the people of Drouin, despite the fact that there is $45 million in the dairy regional communities package to go towards assisting people in this situation.

talk.start.para: —I would like to discuss a couple of the matters that the member for Corio raised. The Labor Party had a conference in rural Australia; I am surprised they got there without a map. Mr Deputy Speaker, let me give you one example today of how the Labor Party is actually taking away from rural and regional Australia. We had Mr Beattie—fortunately, he has seen the error of his ways—removing the fuel subsidy. That is to be restored—and a good thing, too.

speech.para: I want to talk today about the Premier's trawl working group in Queensland. This is supposed to fix the difficulties for the trawl fishermen. Senator Robert Hill has been looking at a viable option for the trawl fishermen. When I was in Bowen last week, the Premier's trawl working group plan was presented to the fishers there. I was fortunate enough to be able to sit in on it. There is no doubt that there needs to be a rethinking of the east coast trawl fishery, and I think the fishers realise that as well. But there has to be a recognition that, in the small fishing towns up and down the Queensland coast, those family trawling operations have got to survive. In towns like Bowen, Ayr and Mackay, there are not the big ships with a hull rating of 65 or 70; there are just the small family fishers.

The Premier's trawl working group plan, which was presented over a four-hour period to the fishers there, asks for a $30 million buy-out. I have to say that nobody is actually opposed to a buy-out for those who want to leave the industry, but the Premier wants $10 million from the state, $10 million from the federal government and $10 million from the fishermen. It would cost each trawl operator about $42,000, on average. That is predicted to reduce effort by 15 per cent. Then there is a further $10 million from the fishers who are left to buy out a further 10 per cent effort. The days and nights allocations are going to be absolutely destructive on family trawler fishermen.

This was given a lot of consideration in Bowen. There was a great deal of discussion and the concerns there were very real. I want the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to hear this: the outcome of the meeting—and these were trawler fishermen from Cairns right down to Hervey Bay—was a unanimous rejection of the day/night proposal in the Premier's trawl working plan. So the Labor Party represents rural and regional Australia? There was unanimous rejection from the meeting of the financial contribution to the buy-out by fishermen. The point that they made was that at least the federal government is trying to put in place an allocation of nights which will allow the family trawl operators to continue working and to relieve some of the burden of the reduction in effort from their shoulders.

It is imperative in our area that the Premier's trawl plan is not the one that gets up because that will get the fishermen out of the industry—not the ones who want to leave—even if this buy-out could be achieved. It is reprehensible that the state government is now going to ask the fishers, who obviously cannot afford it—37 per cent of them are not making a positive income this year—for that sort of money. It is imperative that the federal arrangement of providing a fair allocation that takes account of the family trawl fishermen is implemented.

talk.start.para: —I own a farm and I live on it. When it comes to talking about rural affairs, I feel that I know what I am talking about. If you want to know how well this budget has been received by people in rural Australia, you just have to look at what happened at the weekend at Tweed Heads. The Deputy Prime Minister, the Leader of the National Party, announced an extra $90 million for infrastructure for regional Australia, with a maximum of $500,000 for any one applicant. If they think that is a bandaid, I can tell you it is not going to fix anything. In particular, the towns in my electorate that are going to lose tens of millions of dollars every year because of the loss of income for dairy farmers as the Truss plan wipes out the dairy industry in New South Wales.

—I find it interesting that the honourable member for Richmond comes in here and interjects. He interjects because he knows that the dairy industry in his electorate will be wiped out. We saw the hypocrisy of the black-suited National Party members on Saturday when they stood up and called on the New South Wales state government to provide more for the dairy industry. To make it quite clear, the dairy industry in New South Wales already know the taxpayers of New South Wales are contributing $180 million more than the dairy farmers in New South Wales will receive. Anyone from Queensland should be aware that the taxpayers in your state will be contributing more than your dairy farmers will receive as this plan wipes out the dairy industry in your state, because that is what it is going to do.

speech.para: The point is that another vote has been taken in Queensland, New South Wales and Western Australia. The people who have responded—in the order of 80 per cent of dairy farmers—are saying, `We do not want this plan. It was never explained to us. We did not understand. We did not understand the prices we were going to get for our milk. And now we know, we do not want it because we know we will not survive.' But the tragedy of the plan is that it is not only the dairy producers that are involved; it is whole communities. Whole communities are going to be wiped out. Dairy has been the mainstay of their economy for 1½ centuries, but it will be so no more. After 1 July, this will be no more. The dairy farmers will go immediately. They have started selling up already. The fire sales have begun. They have a herd they cannot sell, they have equipment they cannot sell and they have a property they cannot make a living out of. They will be wiped out in rural Australia where they have always been a feature.

But let us go on. One of the great things this government was going to do was fund transport. They boasted about the massive amount of funding for transport infrastructure. In New South Wales, we got $8.3 million to upgrade bridges in the next year for the whole of New South Wales. But $8.3 million could be used in one year by any one of the local government authorities that I represent; yet that is the amount of money for one year for the whole of the state of New South Wales. That amount would not build a decent two-lane concrete bridge over many of the rivers in the electorate that I represent, and it would not do much for any local government area in outback New South Wales either. But that is what you gave us.

The other hoax that has been perpetrated on the people of New South Wales is the supposed reduction in transport costs. Members opposite know that the government is in negotiations at present with the transport industry, because the transport industry has issued an ultimatum. That ultimatum is that the cost of transport is actually going to go up as a result of the GST. It is going to go up because 80 per cent of truck owner-operators out there know that they are going broke with the rates that they are receiving now. As a result of the letters they have received from the big transport companies demanding that costs go down, they say, `We may as well be out of the industry, because we are broke.' If you believe that the 23c a litre rebate to the transport industry is going to produce your election promise, you know that is false. You know that in the next couple of months you are going to have to go to the people of Australia and say, `Sorry, we made a mistake. Transport costs will go up.'

talker.name: Truss, Warren, MP
Mr TRUSS
talker.role: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

talk.start.para: —It looks like the opposition has run out of steam on agricultural issues. As usual, there are very few contributors from that side on these sorts of issues. If you take away the empty rhetoric and are left with the substance, frankly, they should not have used any time at all, because there was no substance there whatsoever.

speech.para: We had this tired re-run from a number of speakers about the issue of dairy deregulation. The reality is that the government knows that dairy deregulation is going to cause considerable difficulty for dairy farmers, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales. Dairy incomes are expected to fall significantly as milk flows across the border from Victoria and is provided at the manufacturing price that farmers in Victoria have been receiving for many years. It is because we know that there is going to be pain and difficulty in the industry that the federal government responded to the industry's request and put in place the biggest restructuring package in the history of agriculture: $1.78 billion will be available to assist dairy farmers through these difficult times. Time and time again we also get this nonsense line that this is not really the government's money, that somehow or other this is not real money because it is not coming from the government.

talk.start.para: —We just want to know where it is coming from.

—This is pretty typical of the Labor Party's attitude. In a sense, of course, it is true: this is not government money; no money is government money. Governments do not have money of their own. The Labor Party does not believe that. That is why, in office, they spent $96 billion that they did not have and why we now have to pay that money back in the only way that governments pay back money—that is, by getting it from the people through taxes.

speech.para: That is the case in relation to this dairy money as well. It is not money that we have run off on a printing press in the backyard; it is money that we take from people in the same way that all government money comes from the people through taxes. In this case, it is an 11c a litre tax on milk. But it is very real. It is being collected from the same people who pay income tax, fuel tax, stamp duties and all of the other taxes that help to run, provide and support government activities. It comes in exactly the same way that all other tax revenues are raised. This expenditure occurs in exactly the same way that other expenditure occurs. It is a complete nonsense to somehow or other suggest that this government money is any different from any other government money that is being put to an important program.

The other point that I think is very real and very telling is that there are two states in which dairy deregulation is a significant problem, and they are Queensland and New South Wales. It is a problem in those states because the Labor state governments will do nothing to help the dairy farmers in their electorates. They will do absolutely nothing, and that is shameful. These are the states that created the dairy quotas. In some instances they have been collecting stamp duty on the sale of these quotas.

talk.start.para: —Yes, they treated them as property. But now that property right is becoming worthless the state governments are prepared to do absolutely nothing in those states. The reality is that only coalition governments in Australia are doing anything to help the dairy farmers. Nationally the coalition government is putting forward $1.78 billion through its restructuring program. The only other dairy assistance that is available is the program put in place by the coalition government in Western Australia. I congratulate the Western Australian state government on taking that initiative and it is so sad that the New South Wales and Queensland governments cannot see what another state is doing and are not prepared to provide any kind of financial support to the farmers in their states. At the same time as their parliaments are eliminating the regulation in the dairy industry they could be allocating funds to assist the producers in their states—they have it in their power. At the same time as they are wiping out the regulation they should be putting in place a mechanism to ensure the survival of the dairy industries in those states. The Commonwealth will be providing significant resources to Queensland and New South Wales but it is high time the state governments did more and produced real results and ensured the continuing viability of the industries in that state.

speech.para: I will turn to a couple of the other matters that were raised by the opposition speakers who have already departed the committee room and obviously are not too interested in hearing the facts. They are critical now of fuel pricing. I always find it the absolute height of hypocrisy to have Labor Party members coming to this parliament, or for that matter to any forum around the country, and criticising anyone on the question of fuel prices. Labor, when last in office, increased fuel excise by more than 500 per cent. They increased the taxes on fuel, the taxes on country people and the taxes on doing business in regional towns. Labor hiked up the taxes by 500 per cent and yet they have the audacity to come in here and complain that the mechanisms we are putting in place to lower transport costs are somehow inadequate. They actually voted against this reduction in the costs of transport. They actually voted down lower transport costs in the country. The honourable member for Dickson, who was the shadow minister for regional services at the time, in one of her rare comments on this issue actually accused the government of introducing a subsidy on pollution when we tried to reduce the cost of transport. That is Labor's approach to lower taxes on fuel—it is a subsidy on pollution.

Queenslanders have seen, especially over recent days, where Labor really stands on issues like fuel tax with Peter Beattie whipping up a campaign against the fuel companies as a thin disguise to try and put an 8.3c a litre extra tax on fuel in Queensland. He did not quite get away with it in the end. He tried hard. He spent millions of dollars on advertising to persuade the people of Queensland that having an extra 8.3c tax on fuel was actually a good idea. But it did not work and finally he backed away. But no-one in Queensland really believes that the leopard has changed its spots. Everyone knows that Labor will look for the next available opportunity, perhaps just after the next state election if Queenslanders are unfortunate enough to have a Labor government again. Just after the next state election there will be some other new phoney campaign that Beattie will devise so he can put on his extra 8.3c a litre fuel tax to balance the budget so he can spend more money on stadiums in Brisbane. He will find some way of imposing the extra 8.3c a litre tax on country Queenslanders.

I notice that the member for Capricornia has come into the chamber. I hope that, because she gets reasonably close to certain members who have some influence in these sorts of issues in the state parliament, she will be bold and aggressive in telling her state Labor colleagues that an 8.3c a litre tax on the people of Central Queensland and on the people of Capricornia was a disgraceful notion. Any premier who thought that he could pass this off on the people as a good idea worth television, radio and newspaper advertising is out of touch with regional Australia. They need a government in that state that will stand up against these sorts of issues. The people of Capricornia and, indeed, the people throughout regional Australia, should vote against Labor governments that want to impose these sorts of taxes.

The other issue—I think it was about the only other issue—that was raised opposite has already been responded to effectively by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation and that is that, somehow or other, the numbers do not add up in these budgets—that somehow or other $309 million worth of extra money is less. That is the sort of Labor logic that delivers $96 billion deficits, I might say. Let me assure the committee that the reality very firmly is that this is $309 million worth of new money. To compare it with another program, a different program, that was $500 million clearly reflects the inability of the Labor Party to make appropriate comparisons.

There are a number of programs out of the old AAA package which carry through into the AAA2. Those programs are on top of the $309 million worth of new money. In addition, things such as the new farm deposit scheme, which was reformed in the original AAA package and given a costing at that particular time of some $60 million—that excellent program which has provided tremendous benefit for farmers—will be continuing. So those sorts of things are in addition to the $309 million specifically allocated under AAA. This is a good budget for agriculture, it is a good budget for farmers, and it will provide real benefits to rural and regional Australia. (Time expired)
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Family and Community Services

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,752,049,000.

talk.start.para: —One of the great disappointments of this budget was the government's failure to address the issue of residents living in caravan and residential parks. Before the election I attended a number of meetings because, like the member for Richmond, I have a number of people in my electorate who live in parks. I listened to what they had to say, I heard their concerns and I said to them, `Look, I am sure that the government will not ignore your voice. I am sure that they will understand that it is very unfair to discriminate against one group of people in the community as they are discriminating against you.' But guess what? The government has not done anything at all to help them.

speech.para: I had a ray of hope when the National Party conference was on last weekend. And guess what? That came to no avail either. The National Party members of this House were full of fire and indignation when they were at their conference but, two days after they arrived here, they forgot about the people back in their electorates. A series of statements have been made by many members on the other side of this House, particularly National Party members—members such as Mark Vaile who, before the election, said, `No way. There'll be no GST on rental for people living in parks.' The minister, in many cases, has said it was unfair, yet he still ignores the voice of the residents in his area. On 12 October 1999 he said:

quote.para: As you well know, prior to the last election we were very open and transparent about the GST, particularly the relationship it had to rent and particularly the relationship it had to mobile home parks.

speech.para: If that was open and transparent, I would hate to see what it was like when they were covering something up. Last Tuesday a motion was brought before the NSW parliament by the member for Wyong, Paul Crittenden. In that debate the member for Coffs Harbour—who, it seems, has not gone soft on the issue now that he has left the National Party conference—said:

quote.para: I believe that the Federal Government gave an assurance prior to the last election that no-one would be disadvantaged by increased rents.

speech.para: So the friend in the New South Wales parliament of the members on the other side acknowledges that. Mr Howard has increased the rent of people living in caravan parks and I cannot support that. The member for Coffs Harbour, a state electorate very close to the electorate of the member for Richmond, the Minister for Community Services, has stood up in that house and criticised the Prime Minister and said it is not good enough. He went on to say:

quote.para: I stated clearly and loudly at the National Party conference last weekend that I did not support it.
The conference stated unanimously that we do not support a GST on caravan parks.

speech.para: What I cannot understand is what has happened to the National Party members now they are back in this House. I cannot understand how they can let the words of Senator Lightfoot go unchallenged where he said:

quote.para: It might be an incentive for them to get houses.

speech.para: We all know that these people own their own houses. I have a little submission here from some people that live in the Park at Redhead. They are most upset about it because not only are they going to have a GST but they are also getting a rental increase. To say that putting the GST on their rental will get around a rental increase is another furphy because these people are getting a double slug as at 1 July. The points that they make very clearly in their submission to the tax office is that they own their own home; that these homes have got solid foundations and that to move them is a major activity.

This is a very unfair tax. There is still time for the minister to act because this is really disadvantaging residents that live in parks, particularly the ones in Richmond who had counted on the minister. He has let them down badly. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am probably going a bit easier on the minister than the member for Shortland, who preceded me. My comment is a bit of a backhanded compliment in some ways because it is about a program that has been a very good one from this government, but it is disappointing that there has been no additional funding in this year's budget. I am talking about the contact centres that were announced in last year's budget. It is very disappointing that my electorate of Capricornia missed out on contact centres in the last round that was announced for Queensland and that there is no new funding for an expansion of that program in this year's budget.

speech.para: The funding last year was no doubt in recognition of the great need for contact centres that exists in the community and the benefits that they provide to families who are coming to practical terms with the effects of family breakdown. People in my local town of Rockhampton have been raising the need for a contact centre in our city for six months to a year now, since the announcement of last year's funding. The support for this comes from all quarters of the community. It comes, of course, from families who have experienced family breakdown and the difficulty of coming to arrangements for their children and sharing the access to those children. Also, the comments are coming from lawyers who practise in the area of family law and from community workers. I have also been given support from one of the minister's National Party colleagues, the state member for Keppel, Vince Lester, and it is very useful to have that support.

I come to this issue also from my own experience at the community legal centre in Rockhampton where I worked for 18 months helping families reach agreements about the care of their children. I did actually have many instances where negotiations were going along quite well and agreement was just about reached, but the issue of where the children would actually be picked up from and dropped off did cause some great concern and often threatened the rest of the negotiations. I have had a number of letters to my office, as the member of parliament for Capricornia, echoing those sorts of experiences that families in my town had gone through, where children were being dropped off at the local McDonald's or the local park, and it was causing great distress. Even if arrangements are reached where the children are to be picked up from home, often one or both of the partners do not really want to be confronted with the new living arrangements of their ex-spouse or ex-partner. The need is definitely great in my community. I am sure that where the program has been set up in other communities in Queensland it is going along very successfully and is making a big difference to the lives of those families who are trying to work out arrangements for shared care of children.

In Rockhampton in Central Queensland the need is exacerbated in that we are the major centre for a large mining area and also for people working in rural industries. It is quite common for families to have mum and the kids living on the coast or in Rockhampton and dad living out in the mining towns during the week or on a property working in those areas. The need for a neutral, easily accessible place for the children to be left while that transfer of access to the children is happening is quite acute in my town. It would actually be very helpful and take a lot of pressure off families by making those arrangements. There are organisations in my town that have expressed interest in putting in applications to provide that service. I am sure that they would do a very fine job if they were given that opportunity. From what they have explained to me, the setting up of a contact centre would not actually be terribly expensive.

As I said, it is a bit of a backhanded compliment because I am pleased that this program is running. I am pleased that there are already 25 centres, as I understand, operating around Australia. I guess the success of those centres only serves to underline the need for a further expansion of this program. I would appreciate it if the minister could assure me and the people in my electorate that it is a program that will be expanded in the future so that we will have the opportunity to apply for funding to provide a centre of that kind in Rockhampton.

talker.name: Anthony, Larry, MP
Mr ANTHONY
talker.role: Minister for Community Services

talk.start.para: —I would like to certainly mention some of the comments made by the member for Capricornia. It is nice to see that she is using this parliament as an appropriate venue to argue some of her legitimate concerns rather than doing as the previous member, although perhaps well meaning, did in playing more politics.

speech.para: The contact centre is a good initiative. It was an initiative by the Attorney-General in cooperation with the Department of Family and Community Services. There have been 25 contact centres that are going out now. I am aware that the previous member for Capricornia was also a very strong advocate of trying to ensure that there were better family relationships in that part of Queensland. I am happy that in the budget that came through, which is what we are talking about today, there were certainly quite a few changes made regarding child support measures which are very appropriate even for that electorate because that was one of the main areas of concern when family relationships were breaking down.

I would just like to quickly mention that the appropriations of this budget are expected to rise to $55.1 billion, which is one-third of the Commonwealth budget, by the end of next financial year. That is an increase from $49.3 billion. The bulk of that expenditure—27 per cent of that approximately $50 billion—goes to the delivery of programs, that is, to family allowance, youth allowance and child care. The other approximately 70 per cent is for service delivery of Newstart, age pension, disability support pension and so on. Of course, this is an enormous amount that is going from the Commonwealth government back to the community to ensure that we have an appropriate social security system. In many ways, why we are having tax reform is to ensure that we have an adequate and fair revenue base to provide a growing social security obligation, particularly with an ageing population.

There has been quite a deal of discussion regarding mobile home parks. It is certainly an issue that I am very familiar with. Many hundreds of people live in mobile home parks, certainly in the electorate of Richmond and, indeed, in many other electorates across Australia. I was very pleased that, late on Monday, cabinet considered some new measures to help those people who live in mobile home parks; principally to help to ensure that there would not be price exploitation by park owners, depending on whether they want to charge under division 40 or division 87. Those measures that were put in place involved a much closer monitoring arrangement by the ACCC. You could not have a better authority than Allan Fels to ensure that there is no price discrimination. A new advisory board was established, headed by Chris Jordan, which is to work in a cooperative relationship with tenants, representatives of tenants associations and the park owners association, along with a renewed focus from the ATO.

I am pleased to announce that the government has responded to assist those people who live in mobile home parks or boarding houses. As of a few moments ago, the government has decided to increase rental assistance from seven per cent to 10 per cent. Of course, this goes right across the board to help low income families, whether you are living in a Labor seat, the Deputy Speaker's seat, in Dawson, Longman or Parkes. This will cost the Commonwealth government around $33 million in additional rental assistance.
