It will ensure that there is adequate compensation, because we know that Australians, whether they are age pensioners, whether they are relying on some type of social security, whether they have got a family, will be better off after 1 July because of the huge tax cuts that are coming through, because of the huge amounts of family assistance—$2.4 billion—going out, because of the changes that are happening to taper rates, particularly when it comes to pensions, and now because of a 10 per cent increase in rental assistance.

It is very good that the government has made these decisions over the last few days. I will be particularly pleased to report these measures back to many of those low income families that I represent in the electorate of Richmond. Indeed, many are represented by my National Party and Liberal Party colleagues. This is a government that listens and acts. That is why this is an appropriate budget with respect to the Department of Family and Community Services.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Health and Aged Care

quote.para: Proposed expenditure, $2,422,762,000.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise a specific matter of some detail in relation to the GST implementation in the area of NHMRC grants and other grants which are received by medical researchers from overseas sources. Obviously, the GST will have an impact in the area of medical research. But the area on which I would like to seek some specific information from the government today is the impact that this will have on funding which is received from overseas grants. The Minister for Aged Care, who is at the table, may be aware that many of our fine medical researchers receive grants from organisations like the National Institutes of Health, the massive American grant funded medical research program; many receive grants from the UK, from the Wellcome Trust, a very substantial private and public combination in the United Kingdom. These grants go to fund medical research work which is undertaken pursuant to an agreement between the researcher and the overseas based funding organisation in Australia. This has gone on for many years and runs admirably and successfully.

speech.para: The GST, of course, when it starts on 1 July, will have a specific impact on this, and it may well be an unintended consequence on the part of the government, or, indeed, the GST may not apply to these grants. However, they are overseas organisations, they are not registered for the GST, and it is unlikely, if not impossible, that they would ever be so registered. The researchers here are performing a service, they are undertaking research work, and they are being paid for it. Many in the research community are concerned that they will effectively lose 10 per cent from their overseas based research grant.

There are many arguments which we can also take up about the impact of the GST on domestic research grants and the way in which that will reduce the effective amount of those grants, but that is not the specific issue which I would like to address this morning; I think that is probably best left to another time. The uncertainty which is currently facing the research community about the impact of this from overseas based grants is much more pressing because many of the institutions are in doubt about the way in which the GST will impact on these grants from organisations like the NIH in America or Wellcome Trust in the UK.

I think it is very important that the government put on the record a specific clarification of whether this will or will not impact on those grants so that the research institutions and the researchers can have the comfort of a specific ruling on this very matter of great concern to them because, obviously, to lose 10 per cent from these grants would have a disastrous impact on their ability to undertake the research they have agreed to undertake.

talker.name: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP
Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP
talker.role: Minister for Aged Care

talk.start.para: —Basically, I am advised that the answer to the question you have raised is that if it is a gift which is free of obligation from overseas, just a straight gift, then there is no GST payable. But if there is an obligation attached to the gift then they can use an accountant or a solicitor and actually claim an inputs tax refund. That is the way in which it can be used.

— I want to raise two issues, and the first one concerns aged care. I was very concerned about the lack of information and also the way in which, in general, the whole question of ethnic aged care has been handled. At the time the Labor Party went out of government in 1996, there was a formal ethnic aged care policy which had been put in place and which was directed towards the idea that there would be an increasing attempt to take account of what was happening in the ageing of the ethnic population.

speech.para: You may be aware, Madam Deputy Speaker, that the situation is that the non-English speaking proportion of the population, in terms of ageing, is increasing at a rate at least 50 per cent higher than for the rest of the population. That means that amongst those who are going into the ageing category there is a much higher proportion who are from ethnic, non-English speaking backgrounds than there are who are not.

In this situation, one would have expected to see in the last few years many more aged care facilities which are such that they deliver services in languages other than English. There was a program, as I said, right up until 1996, started by the Labor Party. What has happened with this program is that the expansion that was promised in the policy of the Labor Party did not occur. In fact, there are circumstances now where we are going backwards in relation to ethnic aged care, or at least we are certainly not moving forward to the extent that is necessary given the huge increase in the ethnic aged population. I ask the Minister, `What is going on here? Why aren't we having many more nursing homes and hostels with services provided in languages other than English?' In some cases, with some of the newer communities, there is not even a single one in big cities like Sydney and Melbourne.

I ask the minister: what does she intend to do about ethnic aged care? Why aren't we spreading and creating more licences for private dealers and public government funded nursing homes and hostels that deal with the diversity of Australia in terms of ethnic aged care?

The other issue that I wanted to raise concerns Aboriginal health. An issue that I raised with the minister—I was involved with it when I was parliamentary secretary—was Aboriginal hearing services. One of the biggest scandals in this country—this has not been publicised in the mainstream media—is the fact that in some parts of our Aboriginal communities, especially outlying areas, up to 50 per cent of the children are deaf or partly deaf. This came about as a result of health policies not taking into account what happens in early infancy: children were not immunised, they were not looked after, and they lost their hearing. In fact, this was only discovered late in the piece when their teachers were wondering what the hell was going on. They thought the children were dumb and could not understand; the problem was that they could not hear.

The hearing services were supposed to put into place a massive program to deal with this issue. The minister has replied that we have experimental programs, that there have been attempts to work up a program, but this problem has been known for years and needs to be dealt with. I want to know what is happening in relation to this matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Thank you for the opportunity to speak here today. It is somewhat coincidental that I wish to speak on two health related issues. As we speak, there is a meeting going on in Dubbo in the electorate of Parkes between Sydney University representatives and some of the local community, which is pushing for the idea of this clinical school. The government announced, as you well know in the last budget, that they are going to fund several clinical schools in regional areas. Several people from my electorate have been working towards this for some time; it has reached a crescendo in the last few months.

speech.para: Last night, Sydney University held some meetings with some of the GPs and other members of the medical fraternity and there is a wider meeting going on today. I would like to draw the attention of the minister to the passionate feeling, experienced right throughout the west of New South Wales, that Dubbo is the ideal place for setting up such a clinical school. The City of Dubbo has about 40,000 people. It services a wide area in the west of New South Wales to Narromine, Cobar, Bourke, Brewarrina and outside my electorate to Coonamble, Coonabarabran and Lightening Ridge. All the people in that catchment area, which probably takes about a third of New South Wales, use Dubbo as the service centre not only for medical purposes but for a whole range of shopping and other service facilities.

I understand that there is a lobby to put one of these clinical schools in Orange. I have nothing against the people of Orange, but I need to point out to those present, and to the minister, that the strength of the argument is to have such a facility in Dubbo. Unfortunately, the member for Calare is not here; he would accuse me of parochialism. The people who live in the Bathurst-Orange area already have access—they have a couple of hours drive across the mountains to Penrith—to a whole range of services that are not available to people in the far west of New South Wales. As well as that, they already have a very strong core of medical specialists and GPs established in the Orange-Bathurst area.

Dubbo itself is reasonably well serviced with specialists and GPs, but there is very much an ageing populating of GPs. I understand that in the order of 10 to 15 per cent of the GPs are aged 59 or more and that several of the physicians are at an age where they are considering retiring. One reason why the physicians are considering retiring is that there is not a critical mass to share their workload with. Implementing a clinical school in Dubbo would certainly recognise the enormous contribution to teaching that these people already play in the base hospital. They have played this role for many years and go virtually unrewarded and unrecognised. I think it would boost the morale of the existing doctors.
Debate interrupted; adjournment proposed and negatived.

talk.start.para: —As I said, implementing the clinical school would certainly recognise the enormous work that has been done in the area of teaching by many of our specialists in the area. I believe it would go towards creating a centre of medical excellence which would break down the perception—and it is only a perception—of many of the city based members of the medical fraternity that if they do come out into the western areas, they will be cut off from their academic peers as well as perhaps from the cultural centre of Sydney. Having this medical centre in Dubbo would certainly go a long way towards breaking down that perception. It would act as a honey pot. We would have more students spending time in the country and see that it is quite a worthwhile place to live. Further to that, it would actually enhance the educational experience of medical students, with their ability to interact through the Royal Flying Doctor Service with large areas of Aboriginal health. There are many significant areas where Aboriginal communities have particular problems in the health field.

speech.para: In conclusion, can I also draw to the attention of the minister the need for a funded MRI in Dubbo when the numbers are on the table again. The same arguments can be put forward for not addressing the need in Bathurst or Orange in that the people in that area already have ready access to that facility. The people in the entire west of New South Wales do not have that access and certainly need it. (Time expired)

talker.name: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP
Mrs BRONWYN BISHOP
talker.role: Minister for Aged Care

talk.start.para: —I was pleased to hear my colleague make his appeal, but there were a couple of points raised by the member opposite regarding planning for aged care facility places for ethnic communities and also some questions relating to Aboriginal hearing.

speech.para: Firstly, I would like to say that with regard to provision of aged care places for people of ethnic background, this government recognises very well that when people from an ethnic background who have come here from another place, in particular, age, they start to lose English as a second language quite early in the piece. It is also important to realise their tastes. Whereas they may have acquired a liking for what we might call mainstream fare, they like again to have the food that is of their ethnic origin. We are very sensitive to those things. Accordingly, we deal with it in two ways. Firstly, under the legislation there are categories known as `special needs', of which ethnic communities are a special need. We have some ethno-specific facilities, but we also have clusters of ethnic groups which are housed together in the same facility where there are people who speak the language of that group and who are sensitive to their very important cultural needs.

I would remind the honourable member that when we took over in 1996 the Auditor-General found that the Labor Party had really let the industry and older Australians down very badly and had left us 10,000 places short. They never reached the benchmark of having 100 places for each population of 1,000 people aged 70 and over. In fact, it had come down and down every year. I am very pleased to tell you that under our planning and our commitment—the Labor Party's last total expenditure on aged care was $2.5 billion—our expenditure on aged care will be $3.8 billion for the year 2000-01.

That is an enormous increase in expenditure. When the allocation of 14,777 places, which I announced earlier this year—the largest ever round—is combined with the places that were issued in the 1999 round, that comes to 22,000 new places to make up for deficit that the Labor Party left, and to make up the growth. When an allocation of places was made under the Labor Party, they had to forever bring them on stream, but under our provisions they only have two years and, if they do not make them operational within those two years, they will lose them. That means that we will be meeting that benchmark with operational places by the year 2002. Our policy is to have special needs recognition—

talk.start.para: —You haven't answered the question yet.
—I am just explaining to you—
—How many are there for ethnic communities?
—We have a provision under the legislation for ethnic communities whereby their special needs and requirements are met and places are allocated to meet those needs.

speech.para: With regard to Aboriginal hearing, we have a program of community service obligations, of which Aboriginal hearing forms a part. The delivery of health services is through Australian Hearing Services. We have an important accent on delivering hearing services to Aboriginal communities. The program that we have put in place is designed, with the additional money that we have put into it, to meet those community service obligations and to ensure that the problems that Aboriginal communities are experiencing are dealt with.

talk.start.para: —Neither of the questions that I raised have been answered by the Minister for Aged Care. I will have to put some questions on notice. I really need to know the answers. The minister says that, in general terms, the number of places has increased, but the point I was making was that not enough has been done to keep the promises made to the various ethnic communities to provide ethnic aged care, especially the ethnic-specific services provided in hostels and nursing homes. That is the issue that I raised and it has not been dealt with.

speech.para: On the matter of Aboriginal hearing, we know it is the responsibility of the Australian Hearing Services, but the point is that more than four years have passed since we set down a program when we were in government to do something about Aboriginal hearing services in terms of immunising every Aboriginal child to ensure they do not become deaf. Not enough is happening. There is a trial program, but for how long are we going to have a trial program? We need to get to the point where every Aboriginal child is immunised to prevent them going deaf. That important national issue ought to be taken up. The government needs to take it up.
Proposed expenditure agreed to.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs

quote.para: Proposed expenditure $899,171,000.

talk.start.para: —I specifically want to go to a couple of issues concerning illegal migrants. The first issue goes to the recent break-outs of illegal migrants from a number of detention centres. I seek information from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs as to whether there was any firm evidence of a coordinated process of breaking out across those detention centres. Secondly, is there any evidence that those who may be suspected of being involved in arranging some of these illegal arrivals to Australia, and/or alternatively any of the legal firms representing these people, may have in any way been involved in coordinating or have had prior knowledge of the break-outs?

speech.para: I also go to questions of illegal entry into Australia through coastal shipping and the contrast between the regulations and penalties that apply with respect to coastal shipping as against airline arrivals. Going to the revenue to the department from airlines, I understand the department collected well over $9 million from the airlines in the last financial year and that this money assists in recouping costs associated with illegal entries through airports.

Immigration approvals in the form of temporary visas are granted to a ship's captain on a bulk basis—that is, when a ship is to be on the Australian coast, immigration approvals are given over the telephone for the number of crew advised by the captain. Is it true that there is no method of verifying the suggested number advised by the captain? I therefore believe that, if that is the case, the shipowner, operator or captain holds a significant amount of responsibility for the accuracy of this information in the same way that airlines have responsibility for this entry control through their operations. I also believe that there is no doubt that flaws occur in this process, whether by design or by error. We do have some statistics showing the number of people slipping the net of the official immigration processes by jumping ship.

talk.start.para: —I think I gave them to you.

—Yes, and unfortunately I had to operate as your post office box to make sure that the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, who has responsibility for maritime in Australia, actually had the information before him. So, one way or another, we are educating the other side of the House—another joint effort.

speech.para: The figures show that 148 were located, as against 263 jumping ship between March 1996 and April 1999. Each airline pays $5,000 per illegal entry. I understand that shipowners and operators pay next to nothing, which is a great contrast with the airline operators in Australia and, I dare suggest, an injustice and an inequity in the Australian system. I believe for that reason the Australian public needs to know why the government is not holding foreign shipowners and operators more accountable for the financial implications of ship jumpers. I believe if it is okay to recoup the cost from airlines, then we should be doing more to recoup the cost from the foreign shipping owners and operators.

It is clearly an issue about accountability and responsibility which has been delegated to the industry, but it is now an issue about revenue and the implications for the public purse. I suggest that we need to know what the government is going to do because it is about a rigorous immigration policy and its operation and it is about the integrity of the system and making sure that current weaknesses with respect to the shipping industry are cleaned up once and for all.

My second issue goes to the problem I have identified which is escalating because the number of foreign ships and foreign crew operating on our coastline is increasing at the expense of Australian jobs. I simply point out that the number of single voyage permits issued to foreign ships in Australia has increased from 421 to 704 since 1996. At the same time, continuing voyage permits have increased from zero to 41. I raise these in passing for the information to the minister for immigration because they clearly identify the fact that we need to act on this front now. It is clearly the government's policy to use the single voyage permit and associated permits in the maritime industry to undermine Australian jobs in that industry, whilst at the same time having the ordinary taxpayer carry the financial burden of a lack of rigour with respect to the policing of people jumping ship and the lack of accountability about the number nominated by the captain or person responsible for the ship. (Extension of time granted) These are very serious matters that I raise. I seek information both on the Iraqi front and on the issue of coastal shipping and accountability of shipping owners.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —Firstly, can I thank the honourable member for his constructive comments. When the break-outs occurred at the detention centre at Woomera it was of concern to me that we may see similar activities at one or other of the other centres. I coined the word `copycat' in relation to the break-outs that later occurred at Port Hedland and Curtin. I certainly have suspicions that may be similar to those entertained by the honourable member, but I can only say they are suspicions. If the honourable member has any information that might assist me, I would obviously welcome it. I do not wish to say anything other than that there are inquiries being undertaken. These matters are still live issues. If we obtain evidence that these were manipulated in any way from outside, we will pursue it vigorously.

speech.para: On the matter of coastal shipping, I had been following the matter. I was away at the time when you asked my colleague, the Deputy Prime Minister, a question on this matter. It has excited my attention.

talk.start.para: —And mine.

—It has excited my attention because, while there are provisions of the Migration Act that apply generally to dealing with unlawful entry, the disclosure of information and other matters, I suspect that the regime, now that I look at it, is not as comprehensive as that which applies in relation to airlines, and I intend to pursue that matter. I thank the honourable member for his constructive suggestion. He will no doubt find that as we are now both aware of it—it had not been addressed when his colleagues were formerly in government—
—We did not seek to destroy coastal shipping. That is the issue.
—There were stowaways and others who landed at times like that.
—It is more than stowaways.

—Let me just say if the issue is one of integrity of our borders, which it is for me, I intend to address it. I am simply making the point that this is the first time it has been raised with me. I was not aware of that apparent shortcoming. If it is a shortcoming I will address it. I would just urge the honourable member to keep in mind the need for integrity. There are other areas of integrity that the government would like addressed in which we would invite your cooperation, particularly in relation to the way in which the courts are involved in undermining the integrity of dealing with particularly the protection system.

speech.para: The government at the moment is beset with requests from the opposition to speed up the processing of people who are in detention. One of the points I would make is that one of the reasons for delay is that the courts have intruded into the way in which protection issues are addressed to a point where the complexity, the undue legalism and the requirement that we make lawful decisions have imposed very significant obligations upon officers and the Refugee Review Tribunal.

One way in which we could effectively speed up the system would be to implement the privative clause. Another way in which we might be able to get out some of the other rorting that is going on is to pass some legislation dealing with class actions. I will continue to work constructively with the honourable member and his colleagues, but I would invite the honourable member and his colleagues to look at ways and means in which they could work constructively with the government.

talk.start.para: —I have many issues to raise with the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. I will begin, first of all, with the mandatory detention policy. You may be aware of the mandatory detention policy that we have here in Australia. We are the only Western country that has such a policy. This policy has been condemned by Amnesty International, the Refugee Council of Australia, the Ethnic Communities Council, the International Commission of Jurists and many other bodies. Nevertheless, the minister seems to take a perverse pleasure at the moment in offending all these organisations and making more and more provisions which are clearly against our commitments in terms of international human rights.

speech.para: I have asked the minister questions on notice about this issue. The minister's response in relation to the mandatory detention issue, for example—he has made this comment on many occasions—has been to refer to a report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Migration of 1994. The committee at that time was asked to report on the mandatory detention issues. There were some disagreements but the committee as a whole approved it at that time. We are talking about six years further on in which the circumstances have dramatically changed, but the minister keeps referring to this report.

In one of my questions on notice to him, I asked, `Have you considered the suggestion of the Refugee Council of Australia, which gave you a very detailed submission that was supported by many other organisations?' What did he say? He said, `The committee in 1994 did not see any reason to adopt such a model.' That model was not around in 1994.

talk.start.para: —It was.
—That model was not around in 1994, Minister.
(Mr Nehl)—Order! The member for Calwell will direct his remarks through the chair and the minister will be silent.

—The minister, as I said, has some kind of bravado when he is being criticised throughout the media and the ethnic media for the inhumane way in which refugee claimants are being treated and the fact that we have a non-discriminatory policy in which everyone is detained. When the minister was answering the member for Batman, he said, `If you give us some further rights through the courts, then we will be able to speed up the process.' The minister could speed up the process in the following way: he could adopt a two-stage process; he could adopt a process where people were initially assessed quickly. Those who were assessed as having a good claim for refugee status initially could then be released into the care of a large number of community organisations that are wanting to look after them.

speech.para: We have many humanitarian organisations in Australia that do want to look after refugee claimants. The minister knows that. They make submissions to him all the time. One place where the mandatory detention policy hit very hard, to the detriment of our international reputation, was on the Kosovar issue. We accepted 4,000 people here as our guests. Most of them returned. There were about 300 who said, `For various reasons we just do not feel like returning.' The minister intimidated them in all sorts of ways in order for them to return. When only a very small number were left, he shifted them, I think, to Woomera, into detention centres. The Albanian community here pleaded with him to allow these people to live in the community until their things were checked. On this whole issue on mandatory detention, the minister is mistaken. (Time expired)

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr RUDDOCK
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: —I will try not to deal with these matters provocatively, Mr Deputy Speaker.
(Mr Nehl)—And briefly, Minister.

—I will endeavour to do that as well. In relation to mandatory detention, it is a matter of law that, if people arrive in Australia without documentation, they are unlawful and, until they can be lawfully admitted into the community, they have to be detained, unless they leave Australia. That law has been examined by a parliamentary committee, as the member said. I have been a minister for 4½ years, so I guess it probably is six years since the committee looked at it. The point I made then—and the point I make now—is that I would be very happy to look at arrangements with voluntary organisations that are prepared to work cooperatively with us. But while I find they are very happy to work to get people released into the community, when I ask them, `Are you prepared to work with us in relation to people who are found not to be refugees to ensure that they are available for removal?' they say, `That's not our function. We're not going to help in relation to any policing role in relation to law. That is your job.'

speech.para: The reason that people are held in detention when claims are being made is to test their veracity. It is to see whether they have substantial claims and to have people available for removal if they have no claims. Canada has recently moved to introduce a system similar to our own for the very reason that it has found that, when people are released into the community, something like 60 per cent of them do not pursue their claims. They just disappear. Vanish. That is the reason why Canada has now implemented a policy of mandatory detention for people who have been smuggled into Canada. Canada is always being held out as being the country that is the example that releases people. Well it, now, has changed its mind because the policy is flawed. Not all people who are unlawful in Australia are detained. The people who are detained are those who arrive unlawfully.

Let me further deal with the issue. If people were prepared to have a trial in which there was ready cooperation to facilitate removal of non bona fide applicants, I would be prepared to look at it. But when they come to me and say, `All we want to do is get them released into the community,' then I am not prepared to look at it.

talk.start.para: —When did you say this publicly, Minister?
—I said it at the time that I was on the committee with you when I was working with people like Marion Le and the Refugee Council, who are the same people, the same personalities—
—This is the first time you have ever said that.
—The member for Calwell will try and control himself.

—The second point I want to make is that, if the honourable member had been listening carefully to the statements I have made in relation to the processing of people who have arrived in Australia unlawfully and are being held in detention at the present time, he would know that I have said that something like 1,700 people have been found to be refugees but they remain in detention. Why do they remain in detention? Because the issues that have not been able to be addressed in the same time frame are the issues of security, public safety—particularly as to whether or not they are criminals—and public health. I have 1,700 people where those issues are outstanding. They are the issues that the honourable member and the advocacy group say have to be addressed as threshold questions before anybody can be released. The only point I am making is that in our processing we have moved to a point where all of those activities are front-end loaded and undertaken right from the beginning, from the time that people arrive. It is not the question of determining whether or not they are refugees that is delaying release; it is the substantial issues that you say ought to be dealt with before anybody is released. It is important that you know that.

speech.para: In relation to the Kosovars, there were certain procedures outlined in the law which I have followed precisely. Sure, there are people who would like to get immigration outcomes. All I say in relation to those is that there are established procedures which they can work through in the same way as anybody else. I have told them about how that can be done. I will continue to deal with those who are here lawfully, as well as those who are here unlawfully, in the way which the law requires me to.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have been told by the whip that I have got only two minutes. I do want to make the point that I think it is unsatisfactory that these hearings are going to finish at one o'clock, when so many other things could have been dealt with. Perhaps better arrangements can be made in the future.

speech.para: I say to the minister that when he talks about releasing these new refugees of course we are talking about the new category. Most of those are in the new three-year category. I want to raise a number of questions about this three-year category and to say that the minister himself knows that he has been very criticised by the premiers of Queensland and South Australia for the conditions of this new category. The conditions of this new category are outrageous in terms of the provisions made for people. It means that they are released into the community with hardly any provisions at all. They do not have the same conditions which other Australian residents have. The most important and serious point is that they are not allowed to bring to Australia their wife or husband—their spouse—or their children. That means a forced separation of these people for three—

talk.start.para: —Yes.

—Oh, he says yes—as if there is no problem with that. What sort of a humanitarian policy is this? For three to five years, Minister, these people are being forced not to be able to join with their own children and spouse; and you think this is a policy that is worth supporting.
—That is right.
—Order! The minister will be silent.

—What has happened to Philip Ruddock, the humanitarian? This policy is an outrage, and you know it is an outrage. For a government that claims that it believes in the family, et cetera, what is going on here? I can tell you, the whole community is disgusted with these conditions. Once these people are considered to be genuine refugees, even if you are going to give them only three years, you could at least allow them to bring their own children and spouses into Australia. This condition ought to be changed as soon as possible.

talk.start.para: —This Sunday, 25 June, it will be my privilege and pleasure to attend the 25th anniversary celebrations of the Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels. Since its inception in July 1975, Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels has delivered a total of 331,854 meals. In the 1999-2000 financial year it delivered 28,339 meals—that is, 130 per day over six runs. In fact, this contrasts with its first financial year of operations in 1975-76 when it delivered 2,384 meals, around eight per day. In the 1992-2000 financial year there were 288 clients in all relying upon this valuable service. The service also relies upon the active contribution of 196 volunteers.

speech.para: I would like to honour the volunteers and committee members who have served continuously since 1975. I refer to Dorothy Begbie, Val Little and Buntie Hughes. Also, Ruth Barlow has been involved with Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels for the past 22 years, and prior to commencing her volunteer duties with Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels she did meal deliveries with St Andrews Meals on Wheels in the city of Brisbane. I also honour Rose O'Brien, who turns 90 this August, who started with Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels back in 1982. She has been with the group for 18 years and was president for 11 years until July 1999 and still does active meal deliveries.

I also honour the original committee: its president, Mrs Gladys Peel, now deceased; vice president, Eva Parer, now deceased; secretary, Buntie Hughes; treasurer, Keith Begbie; roster secretary, Marge Wilson; and committee member, S. Rowland. I also honour the current committee. The president, Mary Low, has a particularly distinguished service with Meals on Wheels, having started her career with Meals on Wheels at Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels originally, and subsequently rising to become state president of Meals on Wheels in Queensland and serving in that position for 12 years. Following her time as state president, she returned to Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels in July 1999 and was appointed president.

From the current committee, I also honour Jack Sexton, who recently turned 90. He has been with Mount Gravatt Meals on Wheels for 17½ years. He started doing deliveries for Meals on Wheels a long time ago. He was appointed treasurer in 1982 and has been active in Meals on Wheels at Mount Gravatt ever since. I also honour Ken Wilson, who has been secretary for 10 years, and the meals coordinator, Ian McDonald. I honour all of those who have volunteered for this valuable service which has been provided to residents of the Mount Gravatt district for the last 25 years.

I would also like to honour today the contribution of the Holland Park Meals on Wheels service which, next Thursday, 29 June, will be celebrating its 30th anniversary. Regrettably, because of my presence in the parliament, I will be unable to attend that celebration. The history is an interesting one. A public meeting was held on 23 June 1970 in the Holland Park RSL hall. It was there that the first management committee was elected. On 13 July 1970, the first meals were cooked and delivered from the kitchen in the church hall. Since that time, the expansion of its operations has continued unabated. There was an expansion of the facilities in July 1985 and the first meals were prepared in that new facility on Monday, 5 August of that year.

Holland Park Meals on Wheels served its one-millionth meal on 28 October 1996. During its 30 years in operation, it has prepared 1,331,481 meals and in the last financial year produced 91,247 meals, with the average number of meals prepared each day being 376. Holland Park Meals on Wheels employs a full-time manager; 11 part-time employees work alongside 270 sterling volunteers. I would also like to honour the committee: its president, Lynne Petie; vice president, Margaret Seto; secretary, Rita Hickey; treasurer, John Leighton; and committee members, Margaret and Bill Hamilton, Rob MacKnish and Roma and Bill Winders. Also, I honour the current manager, Janice Cochrane, who has held that position for the last 12 years.

I honour the immediate past committee, including the president, Arthur Till. Elected for his 16th year as president, Arthur has been on the committee for 30 years and served two years as vice president before becoming president. Arthur's wife, June Till, has also been continuously involved in Meals on Wheels since its inception. I honour the vice president, Lynne Petie; secretary, Rita Hickey; treasurer, John Leighton; and committee members Denis Freeman, Margaret and Bill Hamilton, Rob MacKnish, Margaret Seto, June Till and Roma and Bill Winders. I also honour past presidents: Mrs Pat McAllister, Mrs Dorothy Foreman, Margaret Hamilton, May Boyd, and Arthur Till, to whom I have just referred. I honour all these volunteers who have contributed to this extraordinary service provided to the Holland Park district and I commend them on their 30th anniversary celebrations. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This adjournment debate gives me the opportunity to raise the issue of the RFA in the western region of Victoria. These matters have been debated in the chamber, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, as you would be aware, quite vigorously. In my electorate the RFA has been signed. But I put on the public record the effect of that signing for those timber workers who will lose their jobs and for those people associated with the timber industry who will be disadvantaged. Initially, everyone in the industry thought that 44,000 cubic metres would be the harvested figure. In the final RFA, it was agreed to harvest approximately 27,000 cubic metres. Obviously, this will bring about a change in the regime and inevitably some timber workers will lose their jobs, along with those transport operators who participate in the timber industry.

speech.para: There has been considerable debate by the environmentalists about whether logging operations should continue in the Otways. I put it on the record that it has been agreed that the various coups should be harvested for timber up until the wet season, so to speak, in the Otways. Yet those environmentalists and greens have taken the matter into their own hands. Mr Deputy Speaker, even you may have seen some of the publicity for those people who, in an unlawful manner in my view, have obstructed the timber workers from going about their task to harvest timber in designated areas, in coups that have been agreed to by the Victorian government and by the department. Yet these people have camped there and stopped the machinery and prevented the timber workers from going about their lawful business.

I put on the record that this is a travesty of the Australian tradition of a fair go and of obeying the law of the land. They are taking the law into their own hands. It is nothing more or less than that position no matter how strongly you feel about this debate. This debate is taking place in the federal and state parliaments and out in the field. Yet these people feel that they have the right to prevent harvesting taking place. I think it is regrettable. I know they do have strongly held views about these matters, but it ought to be debated in here. Following the RFA and the national forest policy statement and, also, taking into account environmental needs, both sides of the parliament have agreed that this difficult issue of allocating resources—that is, the timber resources—has been sorted out. As honourable members opposite would well recall, that was a major argument when they were in government.

In fact, only one per cent of the forest area in the Otways is being harvested at any one time—one per cent in any one year is being harvested. Surely it is a reasonable proposition that the timber industry can harvest in a sustainable way timber products that will grow again. In 40 or 60 years those trees will regrow in quite a substantial way. There is evidence that, after the 1939 fires and the Ash Wednesday fires, these forests replaced themselves in a remarkable and regenerative way so that they have returned to their former glory.

I remind members of the House and those people interested in the debate that inevitably there will be devastating bushfires through the Otways and vast tracts of good timber will be burnt as timber has been burnt for the last 2,000 years. It would be a terrible waste of resources. I advocate sustainable timber harvesting of this product so that the timber can be used for Australian industry and we can make a dent on that import bill of about $2 billion.

I encourage the people in the environment movement to listen to the facts of the argument, to understand that in Australia we have the best timber harvesting code of practice probably anywhere in the world. We should adhere to that practice and bring about a reasonable solution to this argument which both sides of this parliament fundamentally agree on. The questionable activities of some people who have a very strong view should be outlawed and those people should not be allowed to move into the forest to prevent good, hardworking Australian timber workers going about their business in harvesting timber in a traditional manner.
The argument about the lack of rainfall over the last three years being brought about by the timber industry is fallacious in every respect. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: —Today, I would like to speak on behalf of a young woman in my electorate. Her name is Sheree Mulholland. Sheree is a hairdressing apprentice who began her apprenticeship in November last year. She has got a job with one of our local hairdressing businesses and, from all reports, she is doing very well and her employer is very pleased with her. The problem is that she is going through what you could say are the best of times and the worst of times. She has got the chance at the moment to achieve something that she has longed to do for a long time, which is to get through her hairdressing apprenticeship and make a career for herself, but she is finding that very difficult because she is under the New Apprenticeships scheme and she has applied under the auspices of that scheme for a living away from home allowance to assist her with living costs while she undergoes that apprenticeship which, as most members would understand, has a very low rate of pay, in recognition of her recent entry into the industry.

speech.para: She has applied for living away from home allowance to Queensland Apprenticeship Services, which is the New Apprenticeships centre in our local town of Rockhampton. Her application for living away from home allowance has been rejected, and this is causing her enormous hardship. I would like to speak on her behalf today in the hope that the minister, David Kemp, will treat her case with due consideration and overturn that decision.

She was rejected because her circumstances were said not to fit the criteria for living away from home allowance. The criteria are that you have actually left your home town or that you are in fact homeless. There is no interpretation of homelessness that I can think of to which you could point to say that Sheree Mulholland is not homeless. Sheree is homeless. Her mum died when she was only a young girl and her father is currently very ill. He is living in supported accommodation provided by the Rockhampton City Council, and that supported accommodation consists of single-bedroom units and it is for men only. I have received a letter from the president of the management committee that looks after and administers those units. I have also had discussions with the president of that committee, and she has confirmed that it is not possible for this young woman to live with her father. So she has no family home as such. Her father is living in this unit which has been provided to him because he is seriously ill at the moment and needs supported accommodation.

I have written to the minister outlining the circumstances that Sheree finds herself in. I wrote on 19 May this year, setting out in some detail the difficulties that Sheree is experiencing. I spoke to the minister's office this morning and they have acknowledged the letter and it is being processed. I would call on the minister to look at the circumstances of this case very seriously. Here is a young woman who has all the opportunities of life ahead of her. She is an extremely well presented and very articulate young woman and I have no doubt that she has a bright future ahead of her. But, at the moment, she is in circumstances where she does not know where she is going to go at night. She is going from one friend's spare bedroom to the next one, and this is no way for her to succeed in her career.

Her employer speaks very highly of her and, having met Sheree and spoken to her on many occasions, I can see why they want to give her all the support they can. I ask the minister not to hide behind semantics and definitions on this. Even if they want to apply the strictest definition of homelessness that you could possibly come up with, I just do not see how Sheree could fall outside that definition. She has no family home; she has no place to live. To me, that has got to be homeless. I ask the minister to look very carefully at the circumstances of this girl's case and to make the decision that she is entitled to a living away from home allowance to ensure that she has the best possible chance of proceeding with her apprenticeship and making a great contribution not only to that industry but to our community.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I have probably told you on a number of occasions previously that in my patch, Townsville-Thuringowa, there is some tremendous science being done through places like the Australian Institute of Marine Science, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, James Cook University, CSIRO and so on. It is just a component of the very diverse economy of my city. I have a very great interest in science. So it is that I am on the Public Works Committee of the parliament and I am very privileged to be able to see many of the science developments that are happening in this country today.

speech.para: Late last year I was able to be on the inquiry into the replacement of Australia's nuclear research reactor at Lucas Heights. At the public inquiry the people giving evidence basically came in just two streams. There was the Australian Academy of Science and all of their ilk giving the most logical, reasoned argument as to why Australia needed and should have a replacement to the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights. On the other side were the Friends of the Earth and all of their ilk and they were giving the most emotional `not a fact among them' type of argument. In fact, some of the evidence given by them was plainly wrong, and I challenged them and was able to point out where the evidence was wrong.

All members and senators would have received an email from the Friends of the Earth indicating that the new research reactor replacement was going to cost $580 million when the Public Works Committee had only approved $286.4 million. I did investigate that because I was concerned that perhaps there was something I did not know, but it came as no surprise to me that the information put out by the Friends of the Earth was again just totally incorrect; it was irresponsible.

When I was investigating this particular claim I found that the origin of the allegation was that the Sutherland Shire Council had obtained, through the freedom of information process, documents from DOFA which were done back in 1997—they were just totally out of date. They were only estimates and they also included operating costs; they were not the capital cost of a proposed new reactor. Moreover, the $580 million figure quoted by the Friends of the Earth was also incorrect out of the documentation, which actually showed the figure to be $527 million. Their media release and this email that was sent to all members and senators made no reference to the source of their figure, that the figure was a DOFA estimate only, that the figure included operating costs and that the figure dated back to 1997.

ANSTO's response was just quite plain: that the document that they sourced the information from was an early working draft, that ANSTO had already held months and months of public inquiries and reviews, that ANSTO was only authorised to enter into a final contract that did not exceed the budgeted figure approved by the Public Works Committee, and that the facts had not changed.

At the bottom of the email that was sent to all of us it says that a new inquiry needed to be held now into what was becoming the `Lucas Heights reactor scandal'. Mr Deputy Speaker, I say to you and to the parliament and to the Friends of the Earth: nobody's credibility is improved by using information and distributing information that they know is incorrect. It is a shame. We do need environmental defenders in this country. We need people like the North Queensland Conservation Council, for example. But in discharging their role they have to be factual in what they say and they have to lead a proper debate in the country. To go off on the emotional side of things, as I have seen in this email, and to use incorrect information is unfortunate and unwarranted. I call on the Friends of the Earth and their like to maintain a proper debate in this country and to understand that Australia does need a new nuclear research reactor.

subdebateinfo.title: Universities: Newcastle University Social Work Department

talk.start.para: —Newcastle University is a wonderful institution in the Hunter. The university has a social work department that I have been working with over a number of years. I have had placements of social work students in my office, both when I was a state member and as a federal member. When I was a state member we had a youth needs study completed in both Swansea and the North Lakes or San Remo area and linking into the high schools and youth programs in those areas.

speech.para: More recently, we had a look at the needs of older people throughout the electorate. Shortland is one of those electorates that has an ageing population—a lot of people over the age of 65 live within it. We then developed what we called an active quality lifestyle forum. We held our first one in November last year. It was extremely successful. Speakers came along and talked about a number of issues. It was not a forum where people talked about nursing homes and incontinence aids; rather, it was a forum where speakers talked about positive issues such as giving older people in our community choices about what they would like to do with the rest of their lives. It was recognising that people may be 65, they may be receiving pensions, but they still have options. Travel, legal aid and a number of other issues were discussed. At the same time, we invited a number of organisations to set up around the hall and present information about their organisations. Those present ranged from representatives of the University of the Third Age right through to representatives from nursing homes at the other end of the spectrum. It was such a success, with in the vicinity of 200 people attending, that we have decided to make it a biannual event.

As I have said, Shortland is quite a spread-out electorate which covers two local government areas. It covers both Wyong and Lake Macquarie. The first forum was held in the Lake Macquarie area. Lake Macquarie Council was very supportive. Jill Bogarts from the council came along. She provided a lot of information to the residents of the area. This time we are holding it at Toukley, which is in the Wyong Shire Council area. We are doing it in conjunction with the Toukley senior citizens. It is shaping up as being a very successful event. In November this year we will be holding one at Belmont, which is again going back to the Lake Macquarie area. I recommend this sort of forum to members in the House. If they are interested in finding out some details of how we run it, I would be quite happy to give that information to them. We have a person in our office who coordinates the whole project.

With the time I have remaining, I will move away from the seniors forum and tell you a little bit about the project that we are doing at the moment in the office in conjunction with the university. We have had a third-year social work student working on a community empowerment project. I have a number of morning teas within the electorate and at those morning teas people have said to me that they feel that government does things to them and they do not have the opportunity to have input into the process. Out of that I went away and talked to a few people. We picked out one section of the community—Belmont. A number of people are involved who are not usually active in Neighbourhood Watch or the progress association. They had their first meeting. They have decided that they are going to work together in an advisory capacity. About 20 people volunteered their services. They were going to work in a volunteer capacity as my advisory committee. The third-year social work student, Margo, finishes at the end of this month and the project is going to be completed by a fourth-year student. This, I think, is an exciting project, something that could be taken out into electorates throughout the country. Once again, I will provide more information on that to the parliament in the future. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to take this short opportunity to put on the record my disgust at and great opposition to the government's intention to increase the price of beer. The government went to the election with a promise about no price increases for beer, and this is one of the biggest broken promises that we have seen. The community is totally outraged, as I am, at this attack on not only ordinary drinkers and ordinary Australians but also pubs and clubs, the people who work in them and, indeed, the very fibre and essence of who we are as a nation. I believe that the GST price increase on beer is totally unfair. It is totally unjust and it is totally unwarranted. The government can go on about different promises that it made, about core and non-core promises, but of all the broken promises this is one of the worst. It is not one of the worst because it has the highest cost. It is not one of the worst because it has the biggest effect. It is one of the worst because people actually believed this promise—they believed that this price increase would not occur. I personally am very disappointed with the actions of the government.
(Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allowed for the debate has expired.
